speakerposition: subtopic
Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, over the course of the past three years the world airline industry has fallen into a deepening financial crisis. Since 1990 the industry has lost in the order of $ 10 billion.
Major factors contributing to those losses were the drop in demand occasioned by the gulf war, and the heightened security threat to travellers, concurrent increases in the price of fuel, all compounded by the subsequent recession.

Like most carriers around the world, the Canadian airline industry has experienced significant losses, high debt loads, a sluggish traffic situation and vigorous price competition. Unfortunately, there are no quick or easy solutions for returning our carriers to financial health.
Both carriers have already taken painful steps to stem the losses. A greater effort to bring cost structures into line with other carriers, however, must now be mounted if Canada is to retain its competitive position in the world aviation industry.
The Canadian industry needs rationalization. Capacity is too great for current demand and prices are too low to cover costs.

The difficulties faced by our carriers have arisen against the backdrop of rapid change in the global aviation industry. The world economy is experiencing rapid change. The globalization of the world economic system has resulted in major restructuring of many of our industrial sectors.
In response to increasing competitive pressures, carriers have consolidated, for example, British Airways and British Caledonian, Delta and Western Airlines, and
KLM and Northwest, both within and, in some cases, across national boundaries.
Carriers have also looked for opportunities to expand their global networks through a variety of partnership mechanisms. Examples of carrier alliances include PWA-Canadian Airlines and Lufthansa, as well as Air Canada and United Airlines.
In addition, the need for more extensive networks has encouraged the emergence of commercial practices designed to maximize a carrier's ability to capture and keep traffic.
Frequent flyer programs are one example with which air travellers are familiar.

The successful carrier of the future must have an extensive network and the means to attract a sufficient traffic base to support the enormous cost that these networks entail.
In the past 15 years a new fixed-cost element has emerged to become an essential feature of providing an extensive network of services. I refer now to the need to have computer and telecommunications technology strong enough to manipulate billions of pieces of information relating to fares, schedules, flights, seats, reservations, yield management, equipment, and staff assignment, as well as other aspects of airline operations and planning. Hence the importance of linking to a computer reservation system, the essential tool for sales and planning.
Very few carriers in the world are generating profits today. In this respect our carriers are not unique. For Canada, however, the trend toward globalization means that the financial difficulties facing our two carriers has put the Canadian industry at a crossroads.
The strategies we now pursue will dictate not only the structure of the Canadian industry but also the international position of our nation's airline industry.

Canada's transportation policy framework is set out in section 3 of the National Transportation Act of 1987. The framework is based on the principle of competition and market forces as the best means to achieve the goals of our transportation policy. This policy has been of direct benefit to travellers through reductions in price and
November 24, 1992

increased services. The government is still firmly committed to this policy.
The policy has as its foundation the need to provide a safe, economic, efficient and adequate network of viable and effective transportation services to meet the needs of travellers and shippers and to maintain the economic well-being and growth of Canada.
In addition, the policy framework is sufficiently flexible to allow Canadian carriers the benefits of investments from foreign interests. As is the case in most aviation countries of the world, however, Canada's policy requires that air carriers be controlled in fact by Canadians.

Some have argued that the competitive principles which underpin our policy may not be sufficiently supported by the current regulatory regime of the National Transportation Act. The peculiar structure of Canada's airline industry, combined with the difficult market conditions that the industry has experienced in the past few years, have led some observers to suggest the need for reinforcement of our regulatory framework. It may be necessary to re-examine the framework to ensure that it will promote a healthy, competitive environment for the airline industry.
Let us look at the proposal of PWA, the Council of Employees and American Airlines.
For several months now, PWA Corporation has been engaged in discussions designed to improve its balance sheet and its ability to compete in the future. On Thesday, November 10, the chairman and CEO of PWA, Mr. Rhys Eaton, and the lead spokesperson for the Council of Employees, Mr. Sidney Fattedad, put forward a proposal for the consideration of the Canadian government.
This proposal requires that a number of conditions be satisfied before it can be completed. Let me outline the conditions in the PWA-employee council-American Airlines proposal.
Government funding requirements: The deal calls for significant amounts of government funding; a guarantee of up to $290 million is required until closing of the deal,
Routine Proceedings
$200 million from the federal government and $90 million from provincial governments. On closing the deal, PWA proposes to repay $100 million to the federal government. After the closing of the deal and for a period of 36 months thereafter, a continuing cushion of up to $190 million, $100 million coming from the federal government and $90 million from provincial governments, is required.
American Airlines investments. American Airlines is prepared to invest $246 million, to be taken in voting and non-voting convertible preferred shares, at the closing of the deal with PWA/Canadian Airlines if certain conditions are met, one of which concerns the Gemini system.
Before closing, the Gemini Computer Reservation Company must release PWA from its contract for hosting services such that a variety of administrative, marketing and data management processing services may be provided to PWA/Canadian Airlines through the American Airlines Sabre system.
American Airlines requires strengthening of PWA's balance sheet. To meet this condition PWA/Canadian Airlines is seeking to raise $125 million in equity by way of public issue and PWA/Canadian employees have stated they are prepared to contribute $100 million to $150 million through salary deductions for a period of three years in exchange for equity.
The agreements call for American Airlines to appoint two members of an eight-member board of directors on PWA/Canadian Airlines. Those members would have ongoing veto rights over certain management decisions, such as appointment of the CEO; annual business, capital and financing plans; capital expenditures over a threshold amount; mergers or acquisitions of assets over a certain amount.
The agreements also call for American Airlines to provide valuable processing services for PWA/Canadian, mainly through its Sabre system, such as operations planning; pricing and yield management; food and beverage support services; international base operations; technical services and accounting.
The agreement also includes the requirement that all current foreign route authorities of PWA/Canadian be in full force and effect as of closing.

These conditions raise for the government a number of difficult issues. In assessing these issues, the government has sought to balance the following considerations: the financial woes affecting the industry as a whole; the large number of direct and indirect jobs at stake; the impressive dedication and commitment of PWA/CAIL

November 24, 1992
Routine Proceedings
employees who are prepared to make a substantial investment in their company; the constraints on the finances of the Government of Canada; the need to not expose the Canadian taxpayer to an imprudent measure of financial risk; the assistance already provided to PWA through the purchase of aircraft at a cost to taxpayers of over $200 million and to Air Canada at the time of its privatization; the requirement of the deal for the federal government to provide financial assistance for an uncertain period of time, because the closing of the deal is dependent on the resolution of issues relating to Gemini, which are currently before the Ontario Court and the Competiton Tribunal; the need for a proposal that will lead to a return to financal stability in the airline industry; and the legal requirement that, at the end of the day, PWA/CAIL will continue to be controlled in fact by Canadians.

Our preference is to look to every reasonable alternative to preserve a competitive airline system in Canada. Given the importance of the issues at hand, the government wishes members of the Elouse to be apprised of the complexities of the issues. All key stakeholders have to be part of the solution.
To this end, the government will provide up to $50 million in financial assistance to PWA in order to provide an opportunity to explore with all interested parties, including provinces and employees, the actions necessary to minimize taxpayers financial exposure and to support a viable Canadian competitive airline system. The minister's statement today contains many comments which we have been seeking over many months to elicit from that side of the House.
It contains, once and for all, a recognition that indeed the Canadian airline industry is in, as it has been for some time, a state of crisis. It acknowledges at last that the existing regulatory regime may not be serving the needs of Canadian Airline employees and consumers of the airline services for competition because it is leading to a lack of competition.
I am sure the minister does not need to be reminded of the statement of his predecessor, now the Minister of Finance, who said in the House of Commons on April 12, 1988: "The results of regulatory reform and the passage of the National Transportation Act have created a new environment and with it a stable, viable and very competitive airline sector in Canada".
Would that it were so. What we have in today's statement-as I say it is better late than never, but at last we have it-an acknowledgement that the structure of Canada's airline industry has led some observers to suggest the need of reinforcement of our regulatory framework and it states: "It may be necessary to suggest a recalibration of the framework to ensure that it will promote a healthy, competitive environment for the airline industry".
It is high time, but perhaps too late, that this minister has finally taken upon himself responsibility for dealing with this vital and important sector. We have gone through this now for many months. We asked him back in February what he proposed to do about what then was a looming crisis in the airline sector.
What did he say then? "It is in the best interests of consumers and the travelling public in this country to have two airline companies that are in the best possible shape. That is what we want to achieve in the months to come."
Mr. Speaker, how much time do I have?

Where has the minister been? What has he been thinking over all this time?
We look at the passage of time in this House and in the committee dedicated to studying these issues. In April, the Liberals on the transport committee said to that committee: "Let us study the problems in the airline industry". At that time, the contemplated transaction between American Airlines and Canadian was in the public news, saying that the discussions were under way, and many statements were being made about it.
The government sent members to that committee to shut down that inquiry, to refuse to permit the transport committee of the House of Commons to look at this crucial issue. In August when the AMR and Canadian discussions broke down and it was proposed that there be a merger between Air Canada and Canadian, again we asked for the transport committee to look at it. Again, the government refused to have the House of Commons transport committee conduct an inquiry into this crucial issue.
To his credit, the chairman of the consumer and corporate affairs committee had the nerve to hold two days of hearings on the issue before the government members on that committee refused to hear any more evidence about the crisis in this crucial sector.
In September we had the execution of an agreement to move toward a merger of Air Canada and Canadian Airlines. At that time the Leader of the Opposition asked that the government take some measures to review, with a high level panel of experts, what would be in the best interests of the Canadian taxpayer, the Canadian traveller and the Canadian Airline employees, to see what we should do and, if necessary, to give financial assistance to both airlines through tax abatement in order that there be time for that inquiry to be conducted.
The issues that the Leader of the Opposition asked to be reviewed are almost the same as those listed in the minister's statement this morning. On September 9 we were asking him to review these things to determine what should be done.
Certainly this is not a simple issue. It is not an issue that has a lot of simple solutions that anyone can put forward. There is a need for study. We are vitally concerned that taxpayers' money not be flushed down the drain in some last minute scheme to save any company that is going down the tubes anyway. That is
Routine Proceedings
important. But the time that has gone by that time that has been wasted on this refusal to listen, this refusal to act, this refusal to talk is what has really cost taxpayers, travellers and airline employees in this country.

Surely it is not a matter of favouring one airline over another, or of saving Canadian Airlines and thus endangering Air Canada. We believe that it is necessary for us in Canada to have two airlines that are competitive on domestic routes. That is the policy which the minister announced here in the House on February 4. There has been no policy to stabilize the aviation industry since then. The problems which have existed since February 4 existed throughout 1991.

Ever since the gulf war and the recession took hold, airline companies have been suffering. This is not news. The Minister of Transport surely can read the financial statements of the airlines as well as other analysts can. The failure to act for so long that gives rise to the crisis we face today has made it far worse, far more difficult to deal with, and created greater uncertainty in everyone's minds.
As to the solution that is put forward today, yes, we need to do a study; yes, we need to be careful with taxpayers' money; but to put $50 million in today without any clear indication of where the government seeks to go is to put a band-aid on a very serious problem while giving us virtually no indication of what outcome the government really hopes to achieve in this matter.
We do not know what conditions are imposed on this $50 million offer of financial assistance. We do not know whether the government has certain answers in mind for the series of questions posed by the minister which would serve as conditions precedent to giving the additional financial assistance that has been stipulated in the transaction that he outlined this morning. We do not know whether the Government of Canada believes that the transaction proposed between American Airlines and Canadian Airlines constitutes a change of control to American Airlines, remembering that the determination of that matter is appealable on public policy grounds to the federal cabinet. It is incumbent upon the government to come forward, to come out of the weeds, and say what it is it thinks of that proposed transaction. We do not know. We do not know what the government's view

is on the long-term competitive possibilities in this industry.
If we do not continue to have two national carriers competing on domestic routes, what does the government have in mind to fulfil the repeated promises of this minister and his predecessors to provide competition in the airline industry in Canada?
We have no notion of that and yet, as I say, these are not problems that have recently emerged. These are problems that have been clearly on the public policy table for months and months and months. It is time this government took its responsibility once and for all and either addressed itself to these problems, came out of the weeds and told Canadians what it thought should be done, or get out of the way and let somebody else take over.

speakerposition: Whip of the N.D.P.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the announcement today that the Government of Canada is going to give Canadian Airlines $50 million with no strings attached, no return to regulation and no forced ending to crazy competition is clearly outrageous.
This is the 82-day solution. Canadian Airlines is losing $600,000 a day. When you work that into $50 million it takes you to Valentine's Day in 1993. That is how much time this government has decided to buy Canadian while it dithers about what kind of long-term solution is needed.
This government has had not months to find a solution; it knew two years ago when I raised it in the House that the airlines were beginning to bleed. This bleeding has continued now to the point where Canadian Airlines is in jeopardy of going under.
The government knew two years ago and failed to act. It failed to take the matter seriously and the reality has come home to roost that the government is now finding itself in a crisis situation and does not know what to do about it. This decision is no decision at all. It is buying time with taxpayers' money.
I want to ask the minister what strings are attached to this $50 million. Is this an equity investment? Is this a loan? Is this a loan guarantee? Is this a gift? What is this? Is it just opening up the tap to allow taxpayers' money to flow through the minister's hands into Canadian and on to the floor as it continues to bleed?
By itself, $50 million is not going to do anything. All it is going to do is buy somebody some time to come up with a solution. For example, does this $50 million give the government a say in the operation of Canadian Airlines between now and the end of the 82 days?
The minister spent a lot of time in his statement talking about the proposal between Canadian and American, the employees and laying the framework for the international crisis in the aviation industry. All that is well and good, but one simple paragraph on the action the government was going to take and all he told us was that Canadian Airlines has a cheque for $50 million and he did not tell us what has to be done with that or what protection there is for the taxpayer with that kind of allocation.
There is no indication in the minister's statement that irrespective of a return to re-regulation he is going to call in Air Canada and Canadian and knock their heads together and say: "Boys, look. We have to stop this crazy competition. We have too many planes leaving the same airport within five minutes of each other, going to the same destinations half full. You have to stop doing that because it is hurting your bottom line". Anybody with a grade two education can figure that one out.
But no, the government has not decided to do that and we do not have to have regulation to do that. The influence of the Minister of Transport can be used to call in the presidents of those two companies to sort it out and provide a solution in the interim that will stop the bleeding while putting in place a long-term solution which clearly, from our perspective, is a return to regulation.
Even in his overview the minister would not use the word re-regulation. He talked about reinforcement of our regulatory framework or a recalibration of the framework.
The reality is that whether it is a policy change or whether it is recalibration or reinforcement, we have to put rules in place that on the one hand protect the bottom line of the carriers so they do not continue to bleed and that on the other hand protect the consumers, the people who fly on the planes, the communities which
November 24, 1992

rely on those planes for their economic development and their ongoing operations as a community.
The other thing that this non-decision does is it continues the difficulty the employees, not just at Canadian, but at Air Canada and the regional partners of the two carriers are experiencing. I have talked to them. I have talked to pilots, to flight attendants who do not know if they are going to have jobs tomorrow. This decision extends that anguish. There will be flight attendants, pilots, maintenance staff, baggage handlers and people at head office who will go home tonight and whose spouses will ask: "What are our chances?" They will not know because this government dithered instead of making a decision and instead of accepting its responsibility to govern, which it got from the people of Canada four years ago this week.
The government bought itself more time because quite frankly, it refused to admit when it accepted the deregulation policies handed down to it by the former Liberal administration that it was wrong. It was the wrong thing to do. It refused to accept that and as a result we have 30,000 or 40,000 people directly who will be going home tonight scared silly about whether or not they have a job and whether or not they have a future.
That is unfair. This government could have and should have and still could make a decision to do more than just an 82-day solution. It could find a real solution to the problems of the industry.
What we see today is an indication of the reality of this government. It cannot make a decision. It cannot recognize that its economic policies have failed. It has shown once again that this government literally is unable to govern and to make the tough decisions it needs to make. Mind you, it is quite good in making those tough decisions when it hurts Canadians, like the free trade agreement or the goods and services tax. It is okay for it to make those kinds of tough decisions. But the really tough ones are when it has to eat crow, has to eat its own words and recognize that perhaps there was a mistake made when it entered into economic regulatory reform. That is the tough decision that it is struggling with and that is why we do not have a decision today.
This announcement says it all. Not only has this government lost the moral authority to govern, but it has
Routine Proceedings
lost the ability to govern. Quite frankly, it is time for the Minister of Transport and the Minister of Finance, who is really running this show, and the rest of them to get out of here before they do any more damage to the transportation industry in this country or generally to this great country that we love. It really is time to call an election and let the people decide.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for several weeks we have been hearing about Canadian Airlines and conversations between the government and that company. That seems rather strange to us because in 1987 we allowed the privatization of Air Canada in order to have free competition in the aviation industry, especially for passenger transport in Canada.
By privatizing Air Canada, which was running a deficit year after year, we gave it the ability to raise cash to renew its fleet. I remember that when we privatized Air Canada, the president of Air Canada at that time said: "We need to be privatized because we need cash to renew our aircraft fleet". It seems that is not exactly what Air Canada did. Instead, this company used the cash to lower its fares in an attempt to kill Canadian Airlines. In a way, it tried to eliminate Canadian Airlines and become the only major carrier in Canada. The way Air Canada acted was rather unfair.
Today, of course, Canadian Airlines is in a difficult position and so is Air Canada. Both companies are in difficulty. I think that if business people are not serious enough to work together to make their companies profitable, that is their problem. They must agree to

November 24, 1992
Routine Proceedings
operate the two companies profitably or they must merge.
I think that merger was discussed several times between Canadian Airlines and Air Canada, but they came to opposite conclusions. I think that private enterprise should be allowed to compete in a healthy way and that is what the government wants, I believe. If there is one company of this size too many in Canada, the two companies need only merge, seriously streamline their operations and make a profitable Canadian company. I think that is the only way to have a fair and just solution.
In that regard, I sincerely hope that the federal government does not meddle in private enterprise by subsidizing one company to the detriment of another. Clearly in this case if we help Canadian Airlines, we will just hurt Air Canada. We will have solved nothing because in a few months or years we will have the same problem: we will have to subsidize Air Canada. In this case we must let market forces operate and the business managers must be serious: either merge if necessary or leave the scene. It is their choice and that is free enterprise. If we want a serious aviation industry in Canada, we must let market forces work themselves out.
I sincerely hope that the companies will make another effort to talk to each other about merging or rationalizing so that Canada can have a solid and prosperous airline.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to introduce today a bill respecting an amendment to the Excise Tkx Act. The intent of the bill is to solve a problem that has existed across the country in connection with the goods and services tax.
The great complaint about this tax is that it is visible or it is demanded by retailers at every sale. The trouble is that right throughout Canada we have provincial sales taxes as well. Every time someone goes to the store to buy something, they are faced with the goods and services tax and the provincial sales tax. At no time are the goods being purchased in any way or shape at the price advertised by the merchant.
Merchants know when they are selling goods to the public that there are taxes, and merchants ought to make clear the exact calculation of the tax and advertise the total price, not just the price without the taxes because this causes nothing but misrepresentation and concern to the public.
This bill will demand that when goods are advertised at a price they be sold at that price. If the merchant wants to add tax after, he can always advertise the goods plus tax at 7 per cent. Otherwise the goods are sold at the price advertised.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I had to rush to the House to address my colleagues on Bill C-86.

It has been five months since we introduced Bill C-86 and since then the bill has been subjected to intense, detailed and exhaustive scrutiny by members of the legislative committee, by the Senate committee in its pre-study of the bill, by hundreds of individuals and organizations representing Canadians from all walks of life, and through their briefs, representations and presentations by members on both sides of the House at report stage.
With the exception of the behaviour that we saw last night by a party in this House, I have been impressed time and time again by the constructive co-operation demonstrated by everyone involved in the passage of this
November 24, 1992

bill. Members of the legislative and Senate committees have repeatedly demonstrated a deep appreciation of what immigration means to this country and a genuine concern to ensure that the measures proposed by Bill C-86 are fair, practical and in the best interests of Canada.
I have followed with particular interest the work of the Senate committee which submitted a pre-study report that showed considerable care and deliberation. The Senate pre-study report concentrated on proposed amendments relating to refugee status determination and drew heavily upon the testimony of the first chair of the Immigration and Refugee Board, Mr. Fairweather, and Mr. Chefeke, the former Canadian representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
It is clear that members of the committee listened carefully to the testimony and raised in their pre-study report issues that have been in the forefront of the debate on this very important legislation. I commend them for it. I have not always agreed with what members have said about the bill, but I would like to say that I respect their views. I value the work they have done. This has clearly been an effective legislative process. Bill C-86 has been improved by that process.
What is remarkable is that on issues so often the subject of conflicting and polarized opinion, there has been enough common ground in most cases to work out reasonable amendments to the bill.
I had the chance to hear what the Liberal immigration critic, the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, had to say about the legislative committee and the government amendments. If I can quote him, the member said that there is no doubt this committee has worked better than most committees of which he has been a member and the government listened to reasonable arguments in many cases.
There is widespread agreement that Bill C-86 responds to a real need for change and that it is based on sound principles. Few would disagree that change is necessary if we are to manage immigration effectively and fairly in a changing world.
The effectiveness of our immigration and refugee system is being severely tested by mounting international
Government Orders
and domestic pressures. This is a fact of life. Our current Immigration Act was developed 16 years ago with the experiences of the 1960s and the 1970s as sign posts for the future. In some respects, those were simpler times. It was easier to manage the immigrant selection system and abuses of our program were less pervasive.

The fact is, it is becoming increasingly difficult to meet those objectives in the world of the 90s using the tools of the 70s.
That is why we need Bill C-86. Last June I indicated my commitment and the government's commitment to remain open to constructive amendments to Bill C-86 provided that they did not compromise the principles on which it is based. Let me state those principles once again.
First, and there can be no compromise here, Bill C-86 must preserve the integrity, compassion and humanitarian values of our immigration and refugee programs. Second, our immigration program must continue to serve the best interests of Canada and all Canadians. Third, the proposals must result in better management and control of all aspects of our immigration and refugee programs.
In accordance with those principles, Bill C-86 provides for improvements in three main areas. First, we will be able to make a better selection of candidates for immigration in Canada thanks to a better monitoring and management of categories and numbers of immigrants.
Thus, immigration will continue to contribute to the development of our society and to our economic prosperity in all regions of Canada. Second, we will be able to better protect the Canadian society through more stringent enforcement and control mechanisms in order to preserve the integrity of our programs and protect Canadians against those who take advantage of our programs and break our laws. Third, we will further streamline the refugee determination system in order to improve the effectiveness of an excellent program-recognized as such throughout the world-with fair decisions rendered more quickly.
Those are the three main principles underlying Bill C-86.

November 24, 1992
Government Orders

It is clear that the majority of Canadians recognize the need for changes to the old Immigration Act and the majority agree that the focus of Bill C-86 is right. The focus is right; effective selection and management of the immigration program, better protection against criminals and terrorists and a fair, streamlined refugee determination system.
At the same time, concerns have been expressed about how specific provisions of Bill C-86 might work in practice. That is fair. I have listened to those concerns carefully. In many cases, most notably they have been with respect to the role of the senior immigration officer. Anyone who looks at how we do our work will see that those concerns are simply unfounded.
I am surprised at the lack of foundation because our experience as a country, as a people in Canada and the work of this department is surely not what sparks this unfounded concern. It has to be something else.
In most cases, as I said, there were legitimate concerns. There have been cases where the legislative concerns have been expressed and also cases where ambiguity could be cleared up. The government has responded, as recognized by the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, to those concerns in a responsible and reasonable manner.
Amendments were brought forward to clarify, answer and otherwise improve Bill C-86. To name a few examples, methods have been found to continue to hold refugee hearings in camera. It was not there. It was a concern. It was looked at, considered, and taking the views of the many witnesses and the members of the committee, we brought about that change.
Ministerial oversight of section 46.01(c)(e) and 53.1 of the act will be maintained. It was not there. Reporting requirements for changes to the annual immigration plan have been enhanced and measures to more precisely target criminally inadmissible provisions have been adopted. These changes are a direct result of testimony presented to the legislative committee, recommendations in the Senate, a pre-study report and the comments of other interested Canadians. However, none of the amendments alters the basic goals and principles of Bill C-86. Indeed, I believe that these amendments help to achieve these goals.

The fundamental objectives of our immigration program, either social, humanitarian or economic, are very important.
As a government, we strongly believe that the majority of Canadians share those objectives. We should all be pleased that the legislative review process has identified ways to make Bill C-86 even more effective in achieving these shared goals.

The purpose of this bill is to ensure that Canada maintain an immigration and refugee program that is fair, balanced and effective, an immigration program that can operate in the demanding conditions of the world today, a world which many people simply want us to ignore, but we cannot with the trust that people have given us ignore that reality. That is what Bill C-86 is all about, reality.
I think that the majority of Canadians share these objectives. We should all be pleased that this process has identified ways to make Bill C-86 more effective in achieving these shared goals.
It will give the men and women who deliver Canada's immigration program the tools they need to meet these challenges.
It will ensure, at a time when countries all over the world are facing growing demands to cut back on immigration, that Canada can maintain its tradition as a welcoming, compassionate nation, ready and able to help those in need. It will ensure that at a time when growing numbers of people around the world are seeking to circumvent or abuse immigration programs, Canadians will be protected. That is important. It will ensure that those who wish to come to Canada and those who seek refuge in Canada can expect timely, fair and compassionate treatment.
Before I finish, there is one more point I wish to make. It has been clear since Bill C-86 was first introduced more than five months ago that certain members opposite had little criticism to offer about the substance of the bill. In fact, both opposition critics who are here today praised different parts of the bill. Last night, the NDP abandoned any pretension that it wished to attack the bill itself. Instead, it attacked the process.
November 24, 1992

The NDP tried to introduce gridlock government to Canada. Some time today I expect that attack on process to begin anew. I expect the hon. member for Trinity- Spadina or another member of his party to try and suggest that this bill is being rammed through without due regard to the parliamentary process. That was the premise of the circus last night.
That simply is not true. I am not saying that in a partisan way. I am just asking members to look at the facts. Bill C-86 was introduced more than five months ago. Since then, an all-party legislative committee has spent some 61 hours studying the bill. Most bills in this place receive between 20 and 40 hours of study, fully one-third less than Bill C-86. In fact, of the 73 bills passed by this Parliament since May 1991, I am only aware of two other bills out of 73 that have been studied longer by a committee.
During the study of Bill C-86, more than 110 witnesses from all across Canada, coast to coast to coast, appeared before the committee. Still more witnesses appeared before the Senate committee. By the time third reading is completed today, this bill will have been debated in this House for more than 20 hours. Again, this is well above the average.
When you hear people say that this bill needs more study, think about the facts: Sixty-one hours of committee study; 110 witnesses; a Senate pre-study and more than 20 hours of parliamentary debate.
The record is clear. There has been an exhaustive debate and study of Bill C-86. It is a good piece of legislation. It will ensure that immigration continues to contribute as it has for more than 125 years to the social and economic well-being of Canada and of Canadians. Canadians expect as much. I urge all members of the House, on whatever side, to join in passing this bill.

Mr. Speaker, as I said on other interventions with respect to this bill, this bill represents the most extensive amendments to our immigration laws since 1976-77. It is a bill of 128 clauses, comprising 113 pages.
When the bill was tabled on June 16, which by the way was during the last week of the sittings before we adjourned for the summer, it was brought on for debate after two days. In the committee the minister said that it took him and his officials eight months to prepare this
Government Orders
bill. We all know that he has a large number of experts and officials to help him in such matters. Yet, when he put the bill before the House, a long and complicated bill as I just mentioned, he gave the opposition two days to examine the bill before it was brought on for debate. We were expected on second reading of that bill to speak intelligently about the bill without having really an opportunity to examine it properly.
We were not the only ones. Although I have specialized in immigration to a certain extent and while my colleague from Spadina has specialized in immigration, it was still extremely difficult if not impossible to examine this bill properly in the two days before we started second reading debate. We consulted with immigration lawyers, NGOs and other groups that work full time in this area. They had no time to do it either, so we could not seek their advice.
My point is this. All this pious talk by the government from time to time on parliamentary reform and respect for Parliament and respect for democracy is really a pile of nonsense. Once it brought the bill on for second reading debate in June, as I say two days after the bill was tabled, it immediately introduced time allocation and allowed only one and a half days of debate at second reading.
I give credit to the legislative committee, chaired by the hon. member for Lethbridge, who I think did an excellent job. I see him entering the House. I congratulate him. He was fair. He took a reasonable approach in the committee and agreed to the extension of hearings beyond what was originally planned. He gave, I thought, a good hearing to those people who wanted to be heard. I also give credit to the chief government spokesman, the hon. member for St. John's East, who also took a fair and reasonable approach in the committee. It was principally because of these two members that we were able to get some improvements in committee.
There were improvements in the committee. After what we said in the opposition within the first few weeks after the bill was tabled, criticisms that we raised and then were raised by the witnesses time after time when they came before the committee, the committee finally accepted the soundness of the arguments that were being made and made some changes. For example, as pointed out by the minister, it changed the provisions

Government Orders
with respect to public hearings. The bill provided that hearings on refugee cases would be public. Nearly all the witnesses said that was wrong, that it would put the family of the applicant in jeopardy, that it could put him or her in jeopardy. Therefore, the government changed that. It has now gone back to the old rule, which is that hearings before the refugee board will be, by general rule, in camera and only in public by exception. That was one change that was made.
The committee also changed the very harsh detention procedures that were provided for in the bill. The bill provided that once a person was put in detention for an immigration question, there would only be a review every 30 days. That was a waste of government resources and harsh and unreasonable with respect to these immigrants.
I must point out that immigration detention is not for people who are charged with criminal offences. They would go into the regular court system. This is for people who have not committed criminal offences but for one reason or another are deemed to require detention because they may not appear for hearings or whatever.
In any case, the government agreed to an amendment on that. It also agreed to amend the provisions with respect to fingerprints. All those fingerprints will now be destroyed once the immigrant becomes a Canadian citizen.
To a certain extent the provisions on inadmissibility with respect to terrorism and criminality were changed to make them more reasonable. Changes were also made with respect to the permanent residence card.
Certain changes were made in committee and those changes improved the bill. On the whole, the committee worked well. There were only seven members of this House on the committee: four government members, two members from the Liberal Party, and one member of the New Democratic Party, and this is a House of 295 members.
There are a lot of members in this House who are concerned with immigration and refugee matters. The place where they can get involved is during the debate in this House. As I said, the government only allowed one and a half days at second reading on that debate.
Yesterday, it provided for only one and a half days' debate at report stage with 86 amendments to deal with and has also curtailed the time for third reading, the debate in which we are now involved, to one day.
In this House we will only have a total of four days and those days have already been cut back. Yesterday we lost a lot of time because of the voting on the closure procedure. We lost about an hour. Today we lost more time because of the statements that were made. Although there is an attempt to make part of that up, it is not going to make up the total time.
Here we have an extremely important bill, the most extensive bill on immigration since 1976, on an issue that is causing problems all over the world, in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, the United States and Italy, with the mass movement of peoples and we are only spending a very limited amount of time discussing it.
It is not just the question of involving the members of this House in an issue they are all very concerned with. It also involves the general public. Although the press is allowed to come in and report the committee's work, very little reporting is done of those legislative committees, whereas the proceedings of this House are televised and the general public, not just the experts and the NGOs, can be informed with respect to debate. If the debate only goes on for a few days, there is not much chance to deeply penetrate public opinion on these issues.
I talked about the importance of the issues and why it was necessary that we debate these things at greater length in this House. Experts tell us that the population of the world will increase by three billion people in the next 30 years, by three billion people. That is going to impact on all countries in the world. Right now we have 20 million refugees in the world as a result of civil war, tribal conflict, totalitarian oppressive regimes, drought, hunger and so on, for many reasons.
That is going to increase and we have to give attention in our public policy formulation to these issues. It is not just a question of bringing a bill before the House and ramming it through in a few days. If we intend to develop our immigration policy wisely we need to spend some time on it. How are we going to deal with this vast increase in population in the world? What kind of rules are we going to have? How are we going to balance order with humanity? I do not think we have done that in this
November 24, 1992

debate which is being rammed through in an obscene manner.
We in the Liberal Party have always agreed with a dynamic immigration policy but we also believe controls are needed. The doors cannot be wide open. The flow into our country has to be controlled or else the country will lose the good things which attract people to it. A program of assisting people to integrate into the Canadian way of life is needed. Our party treasures the valuable role immigrants and refugees have played in this country. The greatest eras of prosperity in this country have followed the great waves of immigration, whether it was on the prairies, or in the big cities of Ontario or Quebec. We have had the greatest eras of prosperity following great waves of immigration and some of the controversy which took place with respect to some of them completely disappeared after a few years.
I recall in the 1950s when I was at McGill University that because of the Hungarian revolution against the communist regime, over 30,000 people fled Hungary and came to this country. They are all well settled today. They and their children are doing an outstanding job as Canadians. It is the same with the Czechs who came in a similar situation and the Chileans and the Ugandan Asians and so on. They have all contributed greatly to this country.
As I have said, some improvements were made in Bill C-86 in committee but many of the offensive provisions remain and because of that, the bill is still badly flawed.
Despite those amendments this bill will still make it more difficult for law-abiding, hard-working immigrants to enter Canada. It still puts barriers in the way of legitimate refugees. As a matter of fact, very little was done to deal with that issue in the committee or in the report stage yesterday.
The bill opens the door to inequity and capriciousness in the selection of immigrants and it suspends traditional legal safeguards which are customary in Canada. For example, it provides for deportations without hearings. It provides for the suspension of rights through retroactive provisions. Throughout the entire bill there is an emphasis on enforcement as opposed to fairness and humanitarian values.
Government Orders
Finally, Bill C-86 transfers a lot of matters which are presently in the law and are subject to the control of the House of Commons and Parliament to the minister and his officials who can now change the law by regulation and Order in Council. There has been a massive transfer of authority from Parliament to officials and the minister in this bill and that leaves the whole process open to abuse. We never know from year to year what kind of government we are going to have or what kind of minister we are going to have. We could have a very good minister who believes in fairness and who may use these provisions with wisdom, but we could also have a minister who would not.
Parliament must be in control of these things. We are the elected representatives of the people. There is a role for Orders in Council and while there is a role for regulation where things can be done by the government without consulting Parliament, I believe it has gone beyond that point in this bill.
I want to mention some of the things still in this bill that are wrong and are unacceptable. To begin with, one of the major criticisms of the bill is the new powers given to the senior immigration officer in dealing with refugees at the border. When I say at the border, I also mean at airports, points of entry and so on.
Under the present law, the law as it was before this bill, we had a two-stage hearing for the screening of refugees. The first stage was to decide on the credibility of the refugee's case and also whether the refugee was eligible to go on to the full hearing, the second stage. There was a lot of criticism about that first-stage hearing. It was felt that it wasted a lot of time, it prolonged the process unnecessarily, was costly and really was unnecessary because the overwhelming majority of cases that went to the first stage went on to the second stage in any event. While we wasted a lot of time with this first-stage hearing, it did not really screen out many individuals.
On the other hand, there was due process at that first stage. The refugee applicant had the right to an attorney, he was fully informed of his rights and he was protected in presenting his case at that first-stage hearing.

Government Orders
The government has gone along with the proposal that the first-stage hearing should be abolished and in Bill C-86 has abolished the first-stage hearing. That is good. However, it has given some of the authority that was held by the officials at the first-stage hearing to a senior immigration officer who will now have the right to turn away refugee applicants without any hearing, without any representation by attorney, without any due process.
The refugee appears at the airport or the border claiming refugee status. The senior immigration officer can look at his documents and his papers and on the basis of five criteria that are written in the law can say: "I am sorry. You cannot come in. You cannot even get to the refugee board where you and your attorney can plead your case".
In effect, the government in this bill has put a barrier between the refugee applicant and his right to a fair hearing before the board. In doing that, it has not solved any problems. As a matter of fact, it has gone against the legal and justice traditions of this country in doing that.
The minister in his speech this morning has said that he listened to the concerns about the powers of the senior immigration officer at the border and he says they are unfounded. These criticisms do not simply come from members of Parliament, such as myself and the hon. member for Trinity-Spadina and others who participated in the committee. These criticisms come from lawyers and immigration experts who have worked in the immigration field for years. They say that these issues to be decided by the senior immigration officer are not simply black and white issues which can be decided by looking at documents. There are many grey areas where the applicant should have a right to explain and to plead his case.
But no, the government has not listened on this particular matter and has stuck to the provisions of the bill. We are going to have a bill, we are going to have a law if this continues to be rammed through, where a senior immigration officer, without any right for the refugee to be heard, will be able to turn away that refugee before he ever gets to the Immigration and Refugee Board, which is the board that is supposed to determine whether or not the person is a valid refugee.
There were estimates made before the committee that 45 to 50 per cent of the applicants could be turned away by the senior immigration officer at this first step without any right to be heard by the refugee board.
That is a very offensive provision. We had amendments in committee with respect to that, to change it or to do away with it. For example, I had an amendment which was similar to the recommendation in the report from the Senate. All were rejected. My amendment was to the effect and was four square with the Senate proposal that if the senior immigration officer felt that the refugee was not eligible, then that entire matter should be referred to the Immigration and Refugee Board where it would be examined as a preliminary issue before it examined the substance of his refugee claim. That would be fair because before the board is the full right of due process with the right of representation.
The minister this morning said that he respected and thought the Senate had a great report, but in effect he has refused to agree with most of the recommendations made by the Senate committee, which was chaired by a Conservative senator and has a majority of Conservative senators on the committee. I do not know what is going to happen when the bill goes to the Senate. It will be interesting to watch that. The Senate is going to get a bill that it criticized in many respects and asked for amendments in its pre-study. However, we will see what happens.
Another major issue that was raised by witnesses and was not changed by the government is the whole question of the split decision before the board in recognizing a refugee. Under the present law, when a refugee goes before the Immigration Refugee Board there are two members of the board present. In order to win the case, to be recognized as a refugee, a claimant only needs the positive vote of one of the two members of the board.
That was done by the government a few years ago because it felt the benefit of the doubt should be given to the refugee. Somebody fleeing from a situation of oppression, who has been persecuted because of politics, religion, ethnic origin, tribe or whatever, has their liberty in danger. They flee a country, come to Canada and claim refugee status. The law said that if one of the two members of the board could be convinced, the claimant would be accepted as a refugee.
November 24, 1992

In this bill, the government has now made it mandatory in three areas where the refugee claimant will have to get the votes of both members of the board. It has not really explained why it has done that. Why is it necessary?
The government says the system worked well before the board yet it is changing the rules and requiring two votes in certain matters. We tried to change that in committee. Canada's policy on refugees has always been a bit ambiguous. After World War II there was the UN Declaration of Human Rights; I believe it is article 13 that said a person has the right to seek protection against his own government or her own government from a foreign state. Canada largely ignored that and still selected refugees mainly if it felt they would turn out to be useful economic immigrants.
In 1973 the convention refugee claimants from Uruguay and Chile and generally parts in the south started coming to Canada mainly from countries that had been invaded by U.S. investment, U.S. CIA operations and U.S. arms.
In Canada there was an intense controversy over Sikh refugee claimants which produced the same decision, guaranteeing an oral hearing to anyone in Canada who makes a refugee claim.
This was a human rights landmark in Canada's immigration process. It was a high point. Since then this government has been sliding in the other direction, especially since the end of the 1980s when the Soviet power collapsed and the cold war had ended. Without the communist threat Canada's principles of refugee policy began to veer uncertainly because previously they had emphasized automatically bringing in people who were fleeing from a communist country.
When a boatload of dark-skinned people landed illegally in Nova Scotia and the people welcomed them with tea and sandwiches, the Prime Minister and the then minister of immigration started worrying publicly about invasion. You would think they came ashore with machine guns or bazookas or something. All they came with were dark skins. Canada's policy began to waiver then.
I want to look quickly at post World War II migration patterns. They concern some other countries more than Canada but Canada is part of the North Atlantic bloc. Especially I want to look at the migration patterns of dark-skinned people to the United States, the chief world investor in the past four decades, including in those countries in the south which are sometimes called Third World countries.
Investing first began in industrialized agriculture in those countries, replacing subsistence farming with agribusiness, cash-cropping for export to the United States and northwestern Europe.

human condition as a result of our coming from nuclear families and the tribalism that affects us all.
The fact of the matter is that it would be a lot easier for the Conservative members of Parliament, the Conservative government and the Prime Minister to cut that back because of this mythology. It is a myth that immigrants and refugees take away jobs from Canadians. It is exactly the opposite.
If the argument were true that immigrants take jobs away and leave the country poor, Canada would be very poor because with the exception of one million aboriginal peoples in this country, we are all immigrants and the country has done very well; we are number one, as the United Nations points out, of all the countries in the world.
The Conservative members of Parliament and the Prime Minister deserve a lot of credit and plaudits for standing up to the mythology and saying we are in tough times because we are making this enormous adjustment from an industrial manufacturing infrastructure to a post-industrial information microchip service industry in which banking and commerce and all of those types of things are more important. That is an enormous adjustment for the people to have to make but it has to be made.
In spite of that we have the vision and the courage to keep the immigration and refugee level up because it is important for other parts of the world and because it is important for Canada. The underlying point I would like to make and which I believe passionately is that the world will not long permit 26 million people to occupy this vast, rich, bountiful country.
If we existed anywhere else in the world except next to the United States we would have long ago been taken over. If these 26 million people lived next to China or India or the other high population areas of the world, they would have swept in and took us over. They would not have been able to stop themselves. It is only because we are next to that mighty democracy to the south of us, and even it tried in 1812 and soon realized that Canadians were not going to put up with that. Nonetheless, we would not have been as successful against other people as we were against the Americans.
Refugee protection is another important arm of this bill and refugees constitute about 20 per cent of the
250,000	people who come in on average. The third

component is economic growth. That is about 16 per cent.
Another way of looking at it is that for each 100 people who come in, only 16 are coming because of their skills. That has gone on for a number years and because we believe in family reunification, those people, that 16 per cent, are able to then sponsor their immediate families; sisters, siblings, parents and children.
They are also able to assist another group, a broader group than their families, which permits them to get into the extended family and the clan basis which is so important to other cultures around the world. I believe we should be proud of that but nonetheless there is a strong body of thought out there that Canada should be selecting a lot more rigorously for skills.
There has been some criticism and I do not believe it is well founded anymore because I believe we as a nation have to stop these bogus refugee claims. The reason is that they block real refugees.
There are some 10 million-plus genuine refugees in camps around the world today. Those are the people our constituents want to help. Instead, an enormous amount of time and an enormous amount of money are wasted in western worlds by a group of refugees who are really asylum shopping or genuine immigrants trying to get ahead of the line by posing as refugees.
That is not fair. I truly do not believe that it is right or fair that we as Canadians should be devoting so much time, money and effort. The Immigration Review Board spends a lot of its time on those types of claims. I really do not think it is a proper way for us to be spending our resources when genuine refugees are languishing by the millions and millions in camps around the world.
There is another reason the refugee process has to be changed a bit. It does protect and continue the Immigration Refugee Board. That process was opposed by many people in 1987. As I said earlier, many of those same groups are now back saying it is a good deal and do not change it any more; they love it. The fact of the matter is
that it needed to be changed, it has been changed, and I think it has been changed in a way that is positive.
I would like to be a bit partisan because I am a member of Parliament and I belong to a political party that I believe deserves more credit than it is getting for many of the very tough decisions that the nation has had to take and which other nations around the world have had to take, even those led by social democratic parties and by liberal parties. The irony of course is that they are being equally criticized in their countries. Canadians need to see that and understand that in a broader context.
Last night was a bit of a fiasco, but I cannot be very critical of it. When we were in opposition we would sometimes get our knickers in a knot too. We would end up forcing the government to vote on all sorts of amendments. We would go into the late hours of the night and sometimes early into the morning.
Canadians need to know several facts about the opposition amendments. In some ways I was amazed at the lack of realism of some of the amendments. Some of the amendments they proposed would have prevented this minister and future ministers of immigration from ensuring that immigration continued to benefit Canada and would cost Canadian taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars.
If most Canadians realized that roughly $1 billion was spent on immigration, they would be angry with us and saying to us that we needed to look at it closely. They are hurting. They feel overtaxed in spite of the good services they are getting in this country. They would want us to look at it very closely.
The NDP proposed several amendments which I believe would seriously undermine the minister's ability to protect Canada and Canadians from terrorists and criminals. In its view, even if we have reasonable grounds to believe that someone is a terrorist or is a member of a criminal organization or has committed criminal acts, that person should be allowed into Canada. That means that if we have police reports or even affidavits from witnesses we would not be able to keep that person out. I just believe, as a question of judgment, that most Canadians would want the minister to have the power and would not want such a person to be here.

My colleagues opposite seem very concerned about the transportation companies. This government has indicated its concerns as well. But we have to recognize this bill does not seek to impose higher costs on transportation companies. Rather, it seeks to ensure that the transportation companies fulfil their responsibility for the people they bring to this country being properly documented. If carriers do so they will not bear any costs. It is only if they fail to check the people they bring here for passports, visas or whatever travel documents are appropriate, that they will be required to pay a fee.
Unfortunately the threat of penalty seems to be the only way we can ensure that they meet their responsibilities, particularly the international airlines. Our domestic airlines have worked very hard and well at making the system work. It has not been true with respect to some international carriers and this bill gives the minister the power to ensure that it happens.
I think the Liberal Party proposed that eligibility decisions for refugee claimants should be made by the Immigration and Refugee Board. I am convinced these decisions are straightforward and factual decisions which can effectively be made by a senior immigration officer.
Moreover, I am convinced that the Canadian taxpayer should not be burdened with the additional cost of up to $200 million over the next five years if we were to agree to have such decisions made by the board.
I could go on and on about it, but I would like to turn to my conclusions. No other nation has an immigration policy as open and generous as Canada. Our welcome reception of immigrants and refugees has given us the reputation as a caring, compassionate nation internationally. People come from many other countries to study Canada's immigration system, the department as well as the Immigration Review Board. They come to learn how we do it.
It is an expensive system and many other countries cannot afford it. I do not think we should be sitting here in our rich splendour, saying that every other country has to come up to our standards exactly and do things exactly the way we do, as long as they are meeting the principle.

As I said earlier we admit some 250,000 immigrants a year. That is up from 80,000 during the last recession. Politically it is certainly easier to reduce.
Canadians are concerned about immigration, about costs and lengthening delays. We must manage our immigration policy. We need a new set of tools and that is what this bill will provide.

Mr. Speaker, to me this legislation is unacceptable because it goes against certain fundamental democratic principles. I would appreciate if the hon. member would comment on some of the points that seem to deviate from these principles. For instance, the right to appeal a decision has been eliminated or substantially restricted.
Another example of what I see as a serious infringement of the rule of law is the use of the principle of guilt by association. I wonder whether the government realizes that under a provision of this kind, Nelson Mandela, whom the Prime Minister hugged repeatedly in front of the television cameras, would have trouble emigrating to Canada.
I would also like some comments on the economic aspects because I think the legislation is not very consistent when it denies work permits to people who claim refugee status, which practically forces them to live on welfare.
In other words, the government cuts off people's income and then has to spend more on social assistance. Whether it is federal, provincial or municipal, it is still taxpayers' money.
I would also like someone to explain why the retroactivity principle has been applied to immigration, which I feel is a contradiction of the most elementary principles of justice.
I would also like the hon. member to comment on the fact that immigration officers are given arbitrary powers which are actually judicial powers in disguise, especially since the claimant in most cases is not entitled to a

Government Orders
lawyer or hearings are held without a lawyer being present, although that right would seem to be one of the basic principles of the law in this country.
I would appreciate the hon. member's comments on these points.

Mr. Speaker, I will try to take my colleague's points in order.
With respect to lack of appeal-and I am not sure if he said lack of appeal-there are proper appeal procedures in this bill. It is true there are not as many steps as could be taken under the old bill, but under the old bill there were cases wherein the legal system was abused. It led to people staying in the country for years and years. Those people did not get status and, as he said, were sitting around. Sometimes they were even on welfare waiting for all this to occur and years passed. Some of them had families back in their home countries.
It is an obligation of the country to have an appeal process and there is one on the proper questions of the law, for example. It has to be an orderly and quick process. That is what this bill will provide. If my friend looks at it carefully maybe he will change his mind.
Turning to guilt by association, that was largely a question of how to word some of the clauses so that a member who belongs to an association abroad, some members of which do bad things, could be blocked. Some members belong to associations where maybe a wing of the group is terrorists and the others are decent people trying to carry on.
We struggled with the wording. The member would have been more than welcome to come to the committee. I am not criticizing him for not being there because he does attend committee meetings. On this one we were struggling for words that would do the job. We had legal advisers and lawyers from the Department of Justice. Outside people had their views. We struggled as members.
Often a certificate is required from the Solicitor General as well as the minister before certain things can be done. Then there is an appeal mechanism through the courts as well. We think we have a mix that will work.
We can always draw examples of somebody working for Exxon Corporation who technically could be blocked, but in the day-to-day administration we know that will not occur. There has to be a certain degree of trust. Even under the existing act we could find wording that would give a minister or a bureaucrat who wanted to be abusive all the powers to do that. That gets back to the general way our society works, which is pretty fair-minded. We have those judges. If somebody gets too far out of line a judge will snap their suspenders and snap them hard.
With respect to refugees on welfare while the process is going through, I am absolutely satisfied the time will be reduced as a result of the screening mechanism and all other administrative changes. It should not take more than six months. The vast majority will be settled within six months. That is not too bad.
When we look at the other provisions of the bill, they say that once a person is admitted all the rest of his or her family can come in instantly. That is a great improvement to the existing situation. We did hear evidence as to how the existing law really did cause some genuine hardships. That will not happen.
With respect to the arbitrary powers, my colleague opposite is probably referring to section 46.01. This is the power of a senior immigration officer to do an administrative review when somebody shows up at the border to see if the person should be admitted. If there is any dispute at all the vast majority of them will go through to the Immigration and Refugee Board. However, I would ask my friend to read section 46.01 carefully. It gives that SIO power. I want to read it because it is not unreasonable:
A person who claims to be a Convention refugee is not eligible to
have the claim determined by the Refugee Division-

-if the person
(a) has been recognized as a Convention refugee by a country, other than Canada, that is a country to which the person can be returned;
That does not seem to be unreasonable. It deals with somebody coming from western Europe, the asylum shoppers. If they are already in the western world, the United States or western Europe, why should we spend time and money going through that process again? They are in the western world. Meanwhile there are millions

of good refugees languishing around the world and we should be bringing them in.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Lethbridge is an eminent lawyer. Over the years I have known him to speak in favour of due process.
I cannot understand when somebody's rights are in jeopardy, as a refugee's are, why he thinks it is all right that he could be turned away by a senior immigration officer without any right of representation, any right to be heard and could be returned to a country where his life or his liberty would be in jeopardy.
I want to refer him to the Senate report. The Senate, which is chaired by a Conservative senator and which has a majority of Conservative members, said that it was opposed to that. It felt that where eligibility is concerned and the senior immigration officer would turn down a person on the basis of eligibility, that matter should be referred to the IRB, which was a unanimous report of the Senate on that point.
All the witnesses from the Canadian Bar Association, the Association of Immigration Lawyers, the Law Union of Ontario and the Association des avocats immigrants du Quebec said that this is an area, the decision-making process before the CSIO, where there should be the right to be heard and the right of due process because serious rights were in jeopardy.
