As an eminent lawyer, I do not see how the hon. member can justify otherwise.

Mr. Speaker, my support is predicated on the actual wording of 4601 which we had a lot of evidence on. We heard the lawyers who came in, and it is quite proper for lawyers to be arguing due process as we all should as members of Parliament and former lawyers. The officials, as I remember, came back and actually were able to show us how these were easily determined administrative decisions and that if there were any doubt about any of that, it would automatically flow through to the IRB.
That is the way it should be. I am saying to my friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace that if that turns out not to be the case, I have absolutely no doubt lawyers will bring applications and they will find a way under law or under equity, as will the judges, to remedy it and declare that section somehow ultra vires of Parliament or they will find it to be a violation of the charter. They will find a way, but I do not think it is going to happen. I looked at it very carefully. I fretted about it but the officials carried my judgment when we got right into it word by word.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate.
Since the early eighties when I was the Minister of Employment and Immigration I felt that the way in which this country deals with those thousands of people victimized around the world is one of our most important responsibilities.
It used to be said that a country is determined by how it treats its least fortunate. In this world of interdependence I think we are as much judged by how we treat the least fortunate around the world.
In that case, I can only say that this bill we are debating in its final reading is a tale of tragedy. First, there is the tragedy of the people we are dealing with. The numbers of refugees who appear on our screens each night on the news are only a small sample of the enormous misfortune and suffering experienced by tens of thousands of men, women and children around the world.
There is a tendency in this country to think that somehow we are threatened by these movements of people.

November 24, 1992
Government Orders
We are very privileged because if you look at what is happening today in Germany, Croatia or Afghanistan, they are host countries that are accepting hundreds of thousands of refugees. The kind of drumbeat of fear and concern that is being raised by certain sources in this country is really one of illusion.
The other tragedy that this debate recommends is what we are doing about it. The bill in front of us represents a major change in the governing philosophy this country has used since the end of the Second World War to deal with these mass movements of people who have been victimized abroad.
It has been one of the important acts of stewardship of the Parliament of Canada to ensure that Canada has an open door policy and not a closed door policy. This bill almost caps what I have seen over the past several years as a major turning away from that philosophy.
It is a major shift in the attitude toward immigrants and refugees as if somehow we have turned them into a scapegoat, something to be feared and something to be cautioned against, as opposed to saying something that is part of our responsibility as a privileged nation to provide for open and active reception.
Just think for a moment that at the end of the Second World War Canada accepted hundreds of thousands of displaced persons who had been thrown up in the turbulence and turmoil of the Second World War. There were hundreds of thousands of Canadians, many of whose sons and daughters are sitting in the House of Commons today because they got that chance.
Think for a moment what happened during the time of the major revolt in Czechoslovakia and in Hungary in the mid-1950s when again Canada opened its doors to tens of thousands of Hungarians, Czechs and Poles who were escaping communist tyranny. We are not talking about small hundreds, we are talking about tens of thousands.
Think of what happened when Idi Amin took over Uganda and expelled the East Indians who had been part of that country for generations. Again, this country was a leader in accepting tens of thousands of people who had been ethnically cleansed from Uganda at the time.
Think of the record that was jointly shared by both the previous Clark government and the Trudeau government, accepting over 200,000 refugees from Indo-China. There were 200,000 in contrast with what happened in this House of Commons when 26 refugees arrived on the shore of Nova Scotia.
We were called back into emergency session of Parliament because it was portrayed by the then minister of immigration as being a national emergency that somehow Canada was going to be invaded by this great hoard. If that was not a clear signal of the changes that we are now beginning to see the final fruits of in this bill, I do not know what was.
It was a clear sense that all of a sudden the government had broken with that continuity of policy. It had begun to take a totally different attitude. It had begun to go back to the days that Irving Abella wrote about in the 1930s in her book None is too Many when the philosophy of the Canadian government was how many to keep out and not how many to bring in.
It was an exclusionary policy based upon sheer discrimination. Sadly, Bill C-86 only brings to a final stage that kind of Draconian, discriminatory closed door attitude that has since become the new hallmark of Canadian immigration refugee policy. It is so ironic and sad in a way to hear the Minister of Employment and Immigration and other members on the other side of the House talk with some pride about the honours that have been given to Canada for our work dealing with refugees, taking a lead.
It is as if somehow this justified what they are doing now without recognizing that the bill that we are now debating contradicts and rejects the very fundamental premises upon which Canada acquired that sense of reputation and distinction. It is turning its back on those previous positions and policies and philosophies that were taken by both Liberal and Conservative governments over the past 45 years.
When the record of this government is written, which will be done in the next six or seven weeks, when the historians finally get a chance to sift through the sand and find out what it did, this will be one of the blackest marks on the record of this government. It is basically saying that rather than responding in an open, generous and progressive way to the incredible problems of dis-
November 24, 1992

placed persons and refugees, of victims of tyranny and economic deprivation, it is withdrawing inside the fortress.
I admit we are not alone. There is no question that is the dominant response by the various neo-conservative governments in the western world, and we are seeing it. Look what happened in Britain a week ago. It refused to take people who had been kicked out of their country in Bosnia. Is our record any better?
I recall with great force the announcements of the minister last summer about accepting 25,000 families from the horrible situation in former Yugoslavia; great fanfare, great announcement, great public photo opportunities, but if you look at the record today, about 150 to 200 families have been accepted. It is disgraceful, absolutely disgraceful.
We see what is happening in Somalia with the incredible human suffering and when representation and pressure were made to see if Canada could bring out particularly orphaned children and others, the response of the Minister of Employment and Immigration was to the effect that they really would not fit into Canada.
Never mind the big cases that hit the newspapers, look what has happened. You can go to any office of any constituency of any member of Parliament in this country and they can tell you what is going on in the Department of Employment and Immigration in terms of exercising some judgment based upon compassion or humanitarian-ism, looking at it case by case to see if there is some kind of judgment call that could be made as the responsibility of the minister.
I recall when I was in that post, Friday nights when I left Ottawa to go back to Winnipeg with two briefcases full of cases to look at, it was the most awesome and heavy responsibility I have ever had in my life because I was making literally judgments about life and death for so many people.
The reason the minister was given discretion in the Immigration Act of 1977 was that some human judgment based upon a sense of fairness or equity or compassion could be exercised. That has ceased to exist. There is no judgment being made, it has been turned into an assembly line. The assembly line is reject, reject, reject. There is no compassion being exercised, there is no sense of justice being used.
Government Orders
The standard formula now is "no point going to the minister's office, it does not care. We know that we will simply get the black dot, the rejection slip".
Look what it is doing. The latest announcement is it is going to set up new immigration processing centres in Vegreville. Vegreville is a great place to have it but are we turning our immigration refugee procedure into an assembly line in which you run the paper through as if it were some kind of mass-produced washing machine? We are talking about human beings here, we are talking about people's lives-people who need the kind of interface with an immigration officer; talking to families, listening to their cases, having officials know there is a philosophy to judge as to whether that case deserves some sort of fair treatment.
Now we are turning it into a paragon of efficiency. Even at that, the government is downsizing the department by 25 per cent. Increasingly there will be less and less human contact and the long lines of refugees sitting in the camps in eastern Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America will never see anybody again. The long lines of people trying to reunite with their families from the Philippines or India will never get to have their applications even considered by the human eye.
Then we get Bill C-86 on which my colleague from Notre-Dame-de-Grace waged a wonderful rearguard action trying to hold back this juggernaut that is moving against us. The government attempts to justify it as a way of getting better control. It is fooling people but it is not telling the truth.
The so-called third safe country principle? If someone has come from a country that Canada considers a proper country of good bona fide credentials then they automatically get rejected at the border under this legislation.
How do we explain that for long periods of time the United States of America under the Reagan and Bush administrations rejected close to 85 per cent or 90 per cent of all refugee applicants from Central America, especially during the turmoils in Nicaragua, El Salvador and now in Guatemala. For ideological reasons the Government of the United States would not accept that someone fleeing terrorism or the death squad in Central America was a bona fide refugee because the government of America was supporting those regimes.

Government Orders
Under this legislation we have to send them back to the United States, which means they go back into the cauldron. They go back where their lives and their families are threatened and endangered.
How can we say that is a criteria that must be honoured not as an exception but as the standard rule with no right of appeal? Look at the story that came out last week. It was I think again a sign of the times. Dr. Sam Ifejika, a member of the refugee board, resigned because he said: "I have been asked to explain my positive decisions a number of times but I have never been asked to explain my negative decisions. The direction of the refugee board is against the letter and spirit of the United Nations convention on refugees and Ottawa's proposed new immigration law would foster this inhuman policy".
This is their own appointment. This is a member of their own board who resigned because he said in effect the whole weight of government policy is: How do you close the door and keep people out?
It really surprises me because this has not been the tradition of the Conservative Party. I recall very well when I became the successor to the minister of immigration, Mr. Atkey, when he said one of the responsibilities of a minister of immigration is to make sure not to open up the Pandora's box of fear and intimidation about refugees and immigration. Yet that has been the underlying philosophy with this government since the day it came in.
It has broken that continuity and it has turned its back on traditions that have been established successively through the St. Laurent, Pearson, Diefenbaker, Trudeau and Clark governments and I am not sure why. I guess we could all speculate as to what would be the reasons for this shift, this major transformation.
I can tell hon. members and I think all my colleagues who are in the House with me would agree that it will not last very long. When there is an election and the people of this country change the government, what is now Bill C-86 will be the law for only a short period of time. This is not the way we would deal with immigrants and refugees around the world. We cannot accept that Canada should so clearly turn its face against its responsibilities. Let us not quibble about that. All those bureaucrats and people who are getting the engine running and putting the pieces together had better make it temporary because it is not going to last that long. There will be a change back to the far more humane and responsible Liberal notion of what to do.
This government may have some short-term satisfaction that it has shown the Reform Party it can be tougher on immigrants than the Reform Party can be, but it is a false victory that will not last any longer than this government will last.
While I have the opportunity, let me just say that another part of the picture is missing. The amendments proposed by my colleague were very important. He said that one of the things which has to be done about the whole area of immigration and refugee policy is to make it more democratic and more accountable. Appointments to the board should be approved by Parliament. Regulations tabled must be put in a way that they can be not only examined but also rejected by parliamentary vote. There must be a far more open system of examination so that it is transparent and visible.
We have also put forward that if there is going to be a proper refugee immigration policy there must also be deep concern for what happens after people arrive here. What are the present figures? I think over half of those who come into this country do not receive proper education in French or English. It is no wonder they become a problem when they are not even given one of the basic tools to survive, which is one of the languages of the land. The Government of Canada continues to shrink the second language programs in this country.
I will not have time to fully get into this and it may be a debate for another time, but there must also be an international response. We cannot pretend that we can solve these problems simply by ourselves. If Canada surely wanted to show leadership in this world, this is an area that we could take on as our own to try to bring the countries of a developed, industrial world, which have wealth and advantage and privilege, to ask: How do we deal with the vast amounts of human suffering? How do we make sure people will not be freezing in the cold of Bosnia this winter, or dying of starvation in Somalia, or being left to neglect in Afghanistan for tens of years, or
November 24, 1992

being left hanging around the camps in the Middle East as they have been for the last 40 or 50 years?
Surely this area has been neglected by all the countries, but because of our tradition and reputation we can provide an important contribution to the world by drawing attention at the G-7 and at the United Nations population conferences for a brand new definition of what is a refugee and how the world comes to grips with an enormous and gargantuan, but singularly human, problem.
I say that we cannot take on that kind of leadership ourselves until we undo this kind of legislation which sets Canada back 75 years.

Mr. Speaker, I have been carefully listening to my colleague opposite make the same statements I have been hearing for the last eight years to the effect that the Conservative government has done nothing good during that period.
I heard him say a moment ago that since we have been in power, in the sole area of immigration all they have heard is no, no, no. I would like to ask him if he remembers-since he was a member of the government before 1984-what were the immigration quotas set by his government compared to the ones our government set in 1992, just to see if he is right in claiming that all we can say is no, no, no and no.

Mr. Speaker, I said that this Conservative government turned down refugees, not immigrants. There is a difference.
Under the Trudeau government, we adopted a new approach toward refugees. We enlarged the meaning of the term refugee. We established several special programs for refugees from Central America, for example, and from Africa and Cambodia too. We also set up a meeting of several host countries in order to develop a common program.
Our principle regarding refugees was to view each case on its own merits, be it on compassionate, fair or other humanitarian grounds. We cannot fail to notice that it is no longer the case these days with a minister who turns
Government Orders
down just about every appeal. That is what I told the hon. member and he knows the situation well.
At the same time, we are in the midst of a recession. We therefore approached unions, management and NGOs in order to establish acceptable immigration levels. A decision should be arrived at in consultation with all these stakeholders.

Mr. Speaker, my colleague just mentioned that it is indeed refugees that our minister is turning down. Is it really humane to let these people wait for six or seven years before telling them if they qualify as refugees? That was the case when I came along in 1984. There were six or seven appeals. People had to wait for six or seven years without knowing whether or not they qualified as refugees and if they were going to be accepted or rejected. At the very last minute, after six or seven years, they were told: "Sorry you are not a refugee, the system does not allow it. You are not included, you are not in the right category". In 1987 we changed the system in order to make the waiting period much shorter and with the new scheme, it will only be six months to a year maximum. Does he not think that what we are offering now is by far superior to what the Liberals had in 1984 and before that?

Mr. Speaker, I remember the time when the hon. member chaired the House sub-committee on immigration. He made several recommendations which were rejected by the government. I quite agree with him, we need an efficient process but at the same time it is extremely important for that process to be fair and equitable. Members made some substantial recommendations but, unfortunately, their own government rejected them.
We would have had a much better system if it had accepted the recommendations made by these members and by the committee. Unfortunately, because of this government's negative philosophy, it will not be possible.

Mr. Speaker, I would point out to you that my colleague from Red Deer and I would like to share the allotted time. I will use about 10 minutes and he will take the rest.
I would like to outline how Bill C-86 will lead to improvements in the management of immigration. Bill C-86 is above all about management. Management requires research, analysis and a systematic step-by-step

Government Orders
approach. However, management in the 1990s requires much more than that.
Legislators today must have the courage to experiment and adapt creatively to the environment. As Gordon Fairweather, the retiring chairman of the Immigration and Refugee Board, said: "The international migration of people is one of the great social issues of this decade".

While immigration may not be at the front of everyone's mind, it is certainly at the back. Polls show that more than half of Canadians believe the country needs immigrants and that we are not accepting too many. Of Canadians, 72 per cent agree that immigrants contribute to Canada's economy and almost 70 per cent believe they add to Canadian culture.

This is not a time for a tougher, closed-door approach to immigration. We are a welcoming people, but please do not take us for granted.
Canadians want good management and they want us to make it easier for families already here to reunite. They want us to block people trying to sneak in illegally and they want us to give preference to immigrants with marketable skills. They want these skilled people settled in areas where those skills are most needed.
Good management is based on values. Although we need skilled immigrants, we have tried not to sacrifice humanitarian values to economic expedience.
The amendments in Bill C-86 will ensure that Canada remains what it is, a very welcoming country. The three pillars of our immigration policy adopted in 1976 have not been touched. Family reunification, protection to refugees and migration for economic growth are still there.

The new bill proposes to eliminate the first level of the refugee determination system by having a fully trained senior immigration officer at the port of entry make key decisions. In certain instances the senior immigration officer will be able, on the basis of facts, to exclude the person from the refugee determination process. I say on the basis of facts because the officer is not called upon to exercise judgment or make a subjective assessment.
Overpowering your staff is not good management. What the senior officer must do is direct every refugee claimant to the refugee determination process. That is the rule, except in five instances where objective facts show that the person should not access the system.

For example, if the Minister of Employment and Immigration and the Solicitor General issue a certificate saying a person is not admissible because he or she is a criminal, then the senior immigration officer has no judgement to make. All he or she says is: "I'm sorry, you cannot access the determination process, you're excluded".
Another way to manage the flow of refugees is to keep accurate records of every newcomer. Many refugees have no identification while others have ID they admit is fraudulent.

With claimants like these, their fingerprints and faces are their only identification. The only way to record their entry into Canada is to fingerprint and photograph them. That is what we mean by adapting creatively to the environment. This is what Canada is. Canada's Auditor General recommended that measure to prevent multiple claims and abuse of provincial and municipal welfare programs.
If someone comes here as an immigrant, we must investigate him. If they just show up with no identification, we have no idea who they are and we are entitled to find out.
When a refugee becomes a Canadian citizen, there is no need to keep his fingerprints. The major amendments to the act are as follows:
First, our officials will be better able to manage our intake of immigrants according to the goals agreed to by provincial governments, the private sector and non-gov-emmental groups across the country.
Second, better control of abuse by detecting people who try to skirt the rules, by preventing terrorists or criminals from entering the country and by removing those who have no right to remain here.
November 24, 1992

Third, better management of the refugee claimant system by making it more cost-effective, fair and humane.

Fourth, we will better manage the needs of provinces and regions by selecting skilled immigrants and bringing them here quickly.
Fifth, we will better administer the program by improving the quality of service, lessening paperwork, speeding up decision making and cutting costs.
We need effective tools for managing the numbers and selecting people who best meet Canada's needs. The current act is deficient in this regard.
That is why Bill C-86 proposes selecting more skilled immigrants, business people and investors to contribute to regional development and help seed our future prosperity.

What we need is a better balance. This is the reasoning behind the proposed streaming of immigrants. These amendments will better enable us to select people who contribute to the labour market. Good management must show measurable benefits.
This shift toward economic migration will not be dramatic. To ensure that the numbers and types of immigrants we let in reflect the plan, the make-up of each stream will also be determined in consultation with the provinces and other interested groups.

Here are some proposed streams. Stream one people will be processed on demand, with no limit to how many are landed each year. Family identification is still central to our policy. However, we have enlarged the family class definition so we have to make distinctions. Families-the father, mother and children, including adopted children-will get priority. The children are not subject to any quota or level. Hence someone already living in Canada can sponsor a spouse, fiance and dependent children including adopted children. Stream one also includes convention refugees who need protection and immigrant investors.
Applicants in stream two are also on a first come, first served basis but they are subject to limits set out in the
Government Orders
plan. People in stream two could include parents and grandparents of people already here and refugees who are government assisted or privately sponsored. It also includes those let in under special programs.
Stream three people are skilled immigrants and entrepreneurs who meet our economic needs. Once our targets are met no others would be accepted so no backlog would occur.
In addition to these three main streams, investors and skilled immigrants will be selected for different regions across Canada according to their needs.
The amendments propose that we select skilled immigrants who are willing to go to areas where those skills are needed. That is, we will impose a condition on their visa that they work in such areas.
Today we impose the same conditions on temporary workers, except temporary workers have no landing rights whatsoever. Now we plan to tell skilled immigrants not only that we will impose a condition on their visa, but we will land them and allow them to become citizens.

If I had to characterize this bill in a few words, I would use the words common sense, for that is what this package is all about. Our legislative framework needs updating for the times. We must start doing things that make sense, that will help us meet the challenges we face today.
Bill C-86 makes sense because it lets people do then-jobs. It makes sense because it means faster processing, according to clearly understood rules, applied consistently-
Personally, I believe that immigration has made a great contribution to Canada and the world. This legislation will ensure that it remains an asset throughout the 1990s and into the future.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his very concise survey of the advantages he sees in the bill.
I would like to ask him at least one question concerning a matter that I am sure he heard raised by quite a few witnesses about what happens, as it does happen, when

Government Orders
the refugee division of the Immigration and Refugee Board makes a mistake, misunderstands the evidence.
There are cases on record to show where they misunderstand the evidence and declare a person not to be a refugee in spite of evidence which indicates the other or the case where evidence comes in later. Perhaps the refugee has not yet left the country but evidence arrives that just was not available at the time he or she was here. Or, there is the case where the country's circumstances have changed for the worst so that if the board decided while it was looking at the case that it was safe to return there could be changes both ways.
Sometimes when a refugee leaves the country it is very unsafe because of the government in power which has threatened to persecute him or has persecuted him. Then there is a change. This happened in Eritrea. Then the Canadian government can pass the information on to the board saying that the government has changed and it is now safe to send people home. However, in Eritrea it was found that the new government was just as hostile to some of the political groups as the old government had been.
How do we get that taken into account? We were told by the government all that would be looked after under humanitarian and compassionate consideration. That is not satisfactory to many people who have been directly concerned with refugees because humanitarian, compassionate consideration is supposed to be for reasons other than refugee status.
I do not know how many times the present minister has risen in this House in response to a question from the opposition asking whether he would use his humanitarian, compassionate powers on behalf of a certain rejected refugee claimant. What he says is: "We have a good refugee system. He has been found not to be a refugee and I am not going to interfere". In other words, his humanitarian, compassionate grounds have nothing to do with refugee status. To say that there cannot be an appeal-

speechtext: Order, please. Time is running out. If the hon. member wants an answer, it is time to end his comments.

Mr. Speaker, the member opposite has just made another great speech on immigration, as usual. His question is three or four fold, but I will try to be as concise as possible.
His question is: what happens when the refugee division of the Immigration and Refugee Board makes a mistake? When making a decision on the basis of the five criteria, the senior immigration officer will have to take into account any change that may have occurred in the country of origin of the refugee claimant.
What the board does presently is to examine each case, determine whether the individual is a refugee or not and, at the request of the minister, review claims that were turned down. We have seen decisions overturned and claimants be granted refugee status following a review.
What if the people left the country after the decision was made? The officer's decision to turn down a claim is based solely on facts, on criteria. It will have the same effect.
I agree with the member opposite because we have been working on the same committee for eight years and I understand his position. There have been instances where there were problems, but-what can I say-nobody is perfect. This is the second time in eight years that we change this legislation.
I chaired the committee in 1987, as some members pointed out, and I worked very hard to have the legislation changed. I had suggested several changes at the time, eight of which were actually incorporated in the legislation, and I will keep on working to have yet more deficiencies corrected in the future.

I appreciate my colleague's sharing his time with me because there are a number of members who want to speak on this bill. I want to commend all members of this House for their interest and participation in this debate.
This is extremely important legislation and we all agree, all of us who sat on the legislative committee and all members of this House, that this country has been
November 24, 1992

enriched by immigration. If we look around our House, with very few exceptions we are all either immigrants or descended from immigrants.
The purpose of this bill is to enable the government to better manage immigration. The idea is to make it easier for legitimate refugees to qualify, to make it faster and more efficient for immigrants to be approved and to also screen out those who abuse our hospitality.
Prior to 1989 the refugee determination system was not as efficient as we would perhaps have liked it to be. That, combined with the increasing number of people who were seeking protection from persecution in their own homelands, resulted in the inevitable long delays. The system, as we know, became bogged down. Rather than give up in despair, the government established the Immigration and Refugee Board and now our refugee status determination system is finally under control. We need to ensure that our refugee program stays that way.
We want to ensure that every legitimate refugee receives a fair hearing. However, there will always be a few who will try to take advantage of our good will. My constituents told me in a survey this summer in no uncertain terms that they do not want an open door for criminals, they do not want those coming in who would abuse their hospitality.
This nation and all Canadians are generous to those in distress, but we do not appreciate being taken advantage of. Our current system for determining refugee status is a considerable improvement over the previous one but it still needs to be more efficient. The vast majority of cases are now processed within six to twelve months but every one of us from our experience in our offices knows of examples that have taken longer than that.
The government's very reasonable goal is to process all claims within six months. Not only do these delays impose additional hardships on people who are accepted as refugees, but they encourage some who will not qualify as refugees to use the process just to stay in Canada. The problem is not with the refugees who are sponsored by the federal government or sponsored by private organizations such as church groups. In these cases the determination and selection process happens abroad and the reception and settlement process for these individuals is planned. The problem can be with people who show up on our doorstep, usually at an airport, and ask for refugee status.
Government Orders
Last year there were approximately 30,000 people claiming refugee status this way; 30,000 potential refugees is not an insignificant number. There are provisions in Bill C-86 to deal with this situation. One provision is to work with the airlines that would bring the would-be refugees to Canada. Air carriers must be held responsible for passengers who have inadequate or improper documentation. In the past four years that number has been about 23,000, or nearly one-quarter of the persons who presented themselves at Canadian airports.
Another consideration is that there are clearly situations in which the person does not need the protection of Canada. These people should be denied access to the determination system. Processing a refugee claim can run anywhere up to $50,000 and Canadian taxpayers should not have to foot the bill for individuals who are simply trying to take advantage of our good nature.
Another consideration is that we are working with a number of national governments to try to stem the practice of people claiming refugee status in several countries, refugee shopping if you will. There is an agreement among some European countries that the first country the claimant enters takes responsibility for processing the claim. It sounds like a good system.
Misunderstanding has arisen on the proposal to give senior immigration officers, or SIOs, increased responsibility in determining whether a person deserves access to our determination system. This is not to be a judgment call on the part of the immigration officer. The criteria for making these decisions are clearly spelled out. The senior immigration officer will receive special training to make these decisions. The SIO will simply look at the five exceptions that would deny access to the individual. If none of these exceptions applies the person would automatically have access to the Immigration and Refugee Board.
The intent of Bill C-86 is to streamline the system. We want decisions to be made faster. Everyone wants them to be completely fair.
Experience has taught us that the current two-stage procedure with a preliminary hearing and a more detailed assessment is not the best way to handle this process. The reason is that over 95 per cent of claimants move on to the second stage. Let us eliminate the first stage which we know is costly but not always effective.

November 24, 1992
Government Orders
We can cut three to six months off the length of time it takes to make a final determination. We can save Canadians tax dollars and work permits can be issued as soon as a claimant has been accepted.
A moment ago I mentioned the problem of claimants arriving without documentation. We also get claimants from democratic countries such as the United States. Confusing as it may seem, some claimants while their claim is pending return to the country where they say they are being persecuted. In these specific cases, we are proposing that both members of the Immigration and Refugee Board who are hearing a claim would have to agree on the person's right to refugee status, not just one member as is the case now.
I hasten to add that in other cases as long as one of the two board members accepts the person's claim, that will be sufficient for refugee status.
I am sure that hon. members will agree that once a person has been accepted as a refugee, we should help that person become a productive member of Canadian society as quickly as possible. Right now there are delays for as long as two years before some people are landed.
Bill C-86 will help us speed up the process of granting permanent residence. These people will be able to include family members in their applications. I know hon. members will agree that people are much happier and more productive when they are together as a family.
I know that hon. members agree that we must protect those who genuinely need our protection. On the other hand, Canadians' tolerance and compassion are stretched to the limit when individuals who do not qualify for refugee status remain here, taking advantage of our generous system.
Bill C-86 will correct this anomaly. The backlog before the Federal Court is so enormous that it could take several years before a decision is reached on a claimant's appeal to stay in Canada. Bill C-86 does not take away anyone's right to appeal but we can speed up the process by having the review conducted by one judge rather than three and having it reviewed in the trial division of the Federal Court. We have limited resources and they should be used to help people who are genuine refugees and in need of our help.
We have all heard the horror stories of criminals who get into Canada claiming to be refugees. This is not a situation that Canadians tolerate. Crime is on the rise in our society and we certainly do not need to import any more of it. Individuals convicted of crimes can already be refused admission into Canada, but what about persons whom we know have been involved in criminal activity but who have not been convicted? Bill C-86 will help us keep these undesirable people out of Canada.
Immigration and refugee determination has always been and will always be a contentious issue and I along with any member of this government will welcome any constructive suggestion on how to deal with this sensitive issue. Let us all remember that Canada has the most generous and open refugee system in the world. We should be compassionate toward people who deserve compassion, but we should act decisively with those who abuse our generosity.
Our immigration and refugee system must continue to earn the respect and confidence of Canadians. It has been and will continue to be an important program for contributing to national unity and prosperity and the measures that we are proposing in Bill C-86 will help to curtail abuse of the system and defend its integrity. I would urge all hon. members to support this extremely important legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I feel privileged to have the opportunity to speak on Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof. Before I get into some of the specific concerns I have about the bill, I would like to say that when you are a member in an urban riding, as I am from downtown Toronto, Canadians should understand that about 75 per cent of the work that we do in our offices is related to immigration. There is not a day that passes without us opening another eight or ten new files on immigration.
This was actually one of the things that shocked me when I was first elected in 1988 because I had always believed that with any immigration difficulties we had a rather large department of immigration coast to coast with the required number of man-years that could basically look after any of these complex problems, whether they are refugees, people claiming refugee
November 24, 1992

status in Canada or Canadians trying to land family members from other parts of the world.
We soon discovered that the reason people came to members of Parliament rather than deal exclusively with the immigration department was that the basic system, the basic machinery, in that department was not really working well.
I do not need to take a political shot here at the government in the sense that when we were in power that our immigration system was perfect and since the Conservatives took over it got a lot worse. This has always been a very difficult department to manage and operate.
The challenge for us is to constantly work at reviewing this legislation and amending it so that it can deal with the complex issues that face us on an ongoing basis. These issues do change, sometimes because of situations that we cannot foresee or crises around the world where all of a sudden we will have large numbers of people who want to claim refugee status in Canada and sometimes the system no matter how well we try to design an act it is just not good enough.
One of the frustrations that we have on this side of the House during this particular debate is the fact that my colleague from Notre-Dame-de-Grace has presented many constructive amendments that were drafted not just by the member alone but were put together and organized by him after listening to many experts from across the country. These experts work on this issue day in and day out, some as professionals and people who have been actual victims of our system, and so our colleague, the hon. member from Notre-Dame-de-Grace presented all of these amendments to this House and the government basically rejected all of these amendments. I find that approach to such a complex issue a little arrogant. We are not trying to settle political scores on this side of the House while we are trying to put forward a constructive amendment to a very complex bill.
If we reviewed the witnesses and reviewed the experience of my colleague for many years, it seems to me in the spirit of trying to design and create better legislation, it would have served the government to be a bit more
Government Orders
receptive to some of these amendments which ultimately would have served all of us a lot better.
This is important because this type of attitude, this rigidity toward the Immigration Act, eventually is transmitted through the entire department and it becomes part of the spirit of the people that are delivering and implementing the act.
I know in my own specific riding I have had such cases. I cite the Dularie Boodlall case. This women was a victim of violence in Trinidad. She came to my office because she had a deportation notice. She had explained to the officials that her life had been threatened, she had been beaten several times, here is the documentation. The police had documented this information. The officials wanted to deport her back to an environment where her husband was living, where she had received threats to her life. The system, the department, rejected her appeal.
She came to my office several times. I know she also went to the member for Tfinity-Spadina and I believe she went to the member for Parkdale-High Park. The various organizations in the city appealed to us and it was only after very forceful representations in this House that the minister reversed his decision and we were able on humanitarian and compassionate grounds to get that specific case reversed.
My point is that we are constantly being presented with cases in our offices. We are constantly receiving representations from churches and other credible organizations where people are pleading for help and quite often even with all of the resources that we have we sometimes cannot get the minister's office to reverse its position.
What concerns me about this legislation is the fact that we, as MPs, will have even less opportunity to take on those very sensitive cases because in this legislation we are delegating so much authority to public servants. Therefore the political culture, those of us who are dealing directly with the people that elect us, will have less to do in our relationship with them. I think this is a basic flaw in the legislation.
It is very important that we put the government on notice that this aspect of the legislation is very weak. It may appeal to an element in our country that tends to be very right wing in their attitude about the way we process

November 24, 1992
and handle refugees and deportations. Taking the humanitarian tone out of the system is wrong.

Mr. Speaker, the recent report by the National Transportation Agency confirms that Canada lacks a policy on national transportation.
Some two years ago this Conservative government cancelled passenger rail service from Sudbury to Winnipeg. Communities like Marathon, Terrace Bay, Schreib-er, Nipigon, Red Rock, Dryden, Kenora and Thunder Bay must rely on highways, which in the north are not great, or expensive airline tickets.
This government has in essence denied passenger rail service to over 350,000 people from northern Ontario. This Draconian measure deals specifically with people. Let me give an example.
Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Kokanie of Thunder Bay, whose son died in The Pas, Manitoba, were unfortunately not able to travel by air or by car since Mr. Kokanie could no longer drive. Unfortunately, because of their disabilities they could not take any means of available
transportation and because the train was not travelling, they could not attend their son's funeral.

PEN has called for Canada, the United States and Mexico to make human rights and freedom of speech a non-negotiable item of the North American free trade agreement negotiations. Mr. Speaker, following a complaint by a merchant in Val d'Or, 14 male letter carriers and one female letter carrier were each suspended five days without pay for delivering flyers too soon.
Normally, a merchant expects quick delivery so that potential customers are aware of a sale as soon as possible.
This was the exception that proves the rule. The customer complained about the negative impact on his sale: 1,500 of his 12,000 flyers were delivered three hours before closing time in Val d'Or on November 16.
Since in other cases management tolerates and even approves early delivery of flyers, there was no need to punish employees who thought they were doing a good job.
The outrageous part of this story is that Canada Post is not imposing the suspension today-I have a copy here-but at the end of April 1993.
Canada Post abuses a system that has become far too authoritarian and I think a suspension is too drastic. A reprimand in writing in the employee's file would have been enough.
Canada Post shows a complete lack of understanding and respect for its employees and as far as I am concerned, the human relations branch of Canada Post in Quebec City and Ottawa deserves no respect either for the time being.

Mr. Speaker, while acknowledging the very serious problems of deficit and debt which confront Canadians, a recent article in the Fraser Forum confirms the improving trend of some important fundamentals in the federal government's financial management. They bear repeating.
One of the most encouraging realities is the reversal from deficit to surplus in the program operating account, excluding debt costs. Eight years ago the federal government spent $16 billion more on program spending than it collected in revenue. Last year the government spent $10.1 billion less on program spending than it collected on revenue, despite the presence of the recession.

The fund is self-supporting, nonetheless the public perception is that the pension is far too generous. For example, some people think that members qualify for pensions too early.
I hope that members on both sides of the House will support a review of members' pensions by an unbiased panel.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, an interesting thing is happening. At this time many people are growing more and more concerned about the sunken Soviet submarine which contains plutonium and the possibility therein for a massive pollution of that particular region of the world, particularly the ocean and the fishing stocks, et cetera. We are also entering an entirely new era where nuclear waste is going to be transported by ship, thus creating the possibility of

November 24, 1992
Oral Questions
having to deal with this kind of situation over and over again.
I say is that perhaps this government and other governments that have a say in this should learn something from this sunken Soviet ship and try to reach an international treaty to prevent the shipment of nuclear waste by sea under any circumstances.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Statistics Canada has released several positive statements pointing to hopes that the economy is beginning a sustained recovery. August, September and October showed excellent increases in the GDP, employment, retail sales, as well as housing and auto sales.
Consumer confidence is improving and emphasis should be placed on this. If consumers return with a sustained level of spending it will help this country tremendously in gaining back a more prosperous standard of living.
Indications from our neighbours to the south point to improvements in growth in the U.S. economy. This will have a direct impact on Canada's recovery.
These are good signs and ones that should give renewed hope to all of our citizens.
