speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in his report tabled today in the House, the Auditor General of Canada stated that as a result of tax loopholes for foreign affiliates, the federal government is losing hundreds of millions of dollars annually.
I would like to ask the Minister of Finance why hundreds of millions of Canadian dollars invested in Singapore, Switzerland, Barbados, the Netherlands and many other countries are tax exempt, while Canadians have had to swallow 32 tax increases in eight years?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the taxation of foreign affiliates is indeed a veiy complex matter. This government took action in 1988 when it introduced the general anti-avoidance rules into the Income Tax Act.
The hon. member must recognize we have to have a tax system that is competitive, that ensures our tax regime is consistent with international norms and that is not more punitive than tax regimes in other countries because that is part and parcel of a positive investment environment. That is what we have been trying to achieve and that is the balance we have been trying to strike.
I am not sure whether the Auditor General has really recognized the actions we have taken with respect to the general anti-avoidance rules.

Mr. Speaker, with great respect to the Minister of Finance, he cannot do his own job and he should not tell the Auditor General how to do his.
In 1987 the Department of Finance announced that it would review the tax rules on interest deductibility of foreign source income and foreign affiliation. More than five years later, in 1992, these studies have not been completed. What is the government waiting for? Why is the government giving a tax break to corporate agencies and people in Hamilton, Bermuda, but not to those in Hamilton, Ontario? Why are there tax breaks to businesses operating in Barbados, another tax haven, and not to businesses operating in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I repeat that in 1988 my predecessor brought the general tax avoidance rule into the Income Tax Act. Again, I remind the hon. member that Canada's tax policy has to be consistent with international norms.
Hon. members stand up in the House day in and day out and talk about a positive investment climate. We need investment in this country and we need to have an environment that is competitive, that encourages competitiveness and that will encourage investment and the creation of jobs.
November 24, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it is clear the government does not know how to administer tax measures.
According to the Auditor General's report tabled this morning, the government had allocated $422 million for preparing, introducing and managing the GST, the goods and services tax.
However, the government spent $808 million, which is twice as much. The GST costs more than was expected, revenues are lower and the deficit is higher than was anticipated, and so forth.
Will the government finally admit that its administration is out of control and go to the people with a general election?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member should be very careful as to how he reads the Auditor General's report. Nowhere in the report does the Auditor General state that the planning, preparation or the administration of the GST is costing more than what was provided to Parliament. Nowhere. I challenge the hon. member to show me. In fact, I had a meeting yesterday with the Auditor General and we concluded that was not the case.
The fact of the matter is that the hon. member is comparing apples and oranges and we are comparing apples and apples, or oranges and oranges. The Auditor General concludes in his report that-

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Some fancy footwork now.
It is twice as much. Can you not count?

speakerposition: Minister of National Revenue
speechtext: They get very nervous when there is an honest answer coming to a falsified question.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
The Auditor General concludes: "We found that there was no departure from reporting requirements for budgetary expenditures. The costs were disclosed in various main estimates by year and were spread among all involved departments and agencies". The bottom line is the same between the Auditor General's report and our projections on the GST.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Finance. On page 49 of the Auditor General's report the Auditor General says: "In September 1990, the Department of National Revenue, Taxation, again advised the Department of Finance about concerns it has with existing legislation. Taxpayers can transfer foreign subsidiaries' losses to their Canadian parents; move Canadian corporation's income offshore and convert income of Canadian corporations into tax-free income".
Why has the Minister of Finance ignored the warnings of the Department of National Revenue on this matter? Why does he consider helping companies to invest in tax havens more important than creating jobs in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as I said earlier, the introduction of the general anti-avoidance rules into the Income Tax Act in 1988 has in effect taken care of most of those issues the Auditor General has referred to.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance says that the introduction of antiavoidance rules in 1988 has taken care of this matter. Then I ask the Minister of Finance, why is the Auditor General of Canada raising a concern about this matter saying that it has not been taken care of in his report tabled today for 1992? You had better check your calendar, Mr. Minister.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Hon. members ought also to place their questions through the Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, I ask the Minister of Finance why he says this matter was taken care of in 1988 when the Auditor General in his report tabled today for 1992 says that it has not been taken care of. Can he explain this discrepancy between the views of the servant of Parliament, the Auditor General, and what he just told this House?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my response remains the same. I will certainly look into it in more detail. However, the fact of the matter is we believe that those issues have been covered as a result of the introduction of the general anti-avoidance rule which was brought in by my predecessor.

November 24, 1992
Oral Questions

speakerposition: N.D.P. House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance who will know that any government's priority must be to find ways and means to put 1,600,000 Canadians back to work, to give them jobs they most sorely need.
The government keeps telling us that it does not have any money and yet in No. 2.58, the Auditor General says that hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue have been lost as a result of corporate loopholes. That is what it says. In spite of what the Minister of Finance is saying about what happened back in 1988, the Auditor General is saying that hundreds of millions of dollars are lost each year because of corporate tax loopholes.
Will the Minister of Finance do the right thing in an effort for fairness and justice in our tax system? Will he close those loopholes, collect those revenues and create those jobs with that additional revenue?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again my predecessor has the record of closing many of the hundreds of tax loopholes which were left there by the previous administration. The fact of the matter is that many of the same members are now saying: "We need some incentives in the system to encourage jobs and to generate investment". I wonder to what specific loopholes the hon. member is in fact referring.
I can tell the hon. member that one of the best ways for his party to contribute to job creation is get off this protectionist kick it is on that suggests we should become a closed economy, that we should not open our doors to trade, that we should not open our doors to investment. That is not our approach.
Our approach is that we are open for business, we are open for trade, we believe in the free trade agreement with the United States and-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Okanagan-Simil-kameen-Merritt.

Mr. Speaker, it seems that the government has had eight years to close those loopholes and it has in fact put all of Canada out for sale.
While the Auditor General points out the tax unfairness between the corporate taxpayers, he also points out that the small business community suffers while our large corporations profit. Will the government now
recognize that the small business community is the future creator of jobs in Canada and will it move immediately to level the playing field for that sector?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
I agree, Mr. Speaker, that the small business community is one of the major components of job creation in this country. That is why we are continually taking steps to encourage the small business sector.
I note one of the tax loopholes that the New Democratic Party refers to at all times is the capital gains exemption that is applied to small business. That is one of the loopholes I suspect it wants to do away with. That would not help small business. It would hurt small business.

Mr. Speaker, it seems that the government's fiscal and monetary policies have created a situation where we have over 1.5 million people unemployed. At the same time we look at the Auditor General's report and we find that the foreign affiliates of Canadian corporations have invested more than $90 billion offshore in offshore tax havens.
Will the minister commit now that this multimillion dollar tax rip-off will be shut down and the money used for job creation for those 1.5 million desperate unemployed people in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I indicated earlier, my predecessor brought in provisions such as the large corporation tax and the general anti-avoidance rules as ways and means to close a number of these loopholes. There is also the fact that the scientific research and development incentive was part of the former administration's $1 billion boondoggle. Those kinds of things were closed. There have been a number of loopholes which have been closed.
If there are any further examples, we will certainly take them into consideration.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the President of the Treasury Board. Today the Auditor General told us that the government gave 22 untendered contracts ranging between $35,000 and $743,000 for the so-called prosperity agenda, all in contravention of Treasury Board rules.
November 24, 1992

I want to ask the minister: Why does this tired old government think that rules are made to be broken? Why does the minister tell Canadians to tighten their belts at the same time as the purse strings are being loosened for Conservative Party hacks and supporters?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me say to the hon. member that this government was off and running with the prosperity initiative drawing out ideas from people across the country. We were developing policies as to how we would respond to the people of this country in bringing about a package of policies which would do exactly what the hon. member wants and that is to move this country into the nineties, into the next century with a series and a composition of policies that are designed to improve the competitive position of this country.
The hon. member asked a specific question about tendering practices. The practices that were followed were consistent with the spirit of the rules. However, because of the urgency of getting the prosperity initiative launched, there was not sufficient time to follow the policy to the letter. It was with a desire to move ahead as quickly as we could that we took this action.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can tell that this is a very tender subject with the government across the way.

My supplementary is for the minister who just answered. The Auditor General also declared today that two thirds of these contracts were paid even before the work was done.
Therefore, I would ask the minister the following: when will this old and tired government learn that the taxpayers' money does not belong to the Tories and that they cannot use it to reward their friends?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is hard for me to understand how the
Oral Questions
member would describe the government the way he has when we are anxious to get out and do things that will help the success of this economy. It is precisely for that reason we have been subject to this comment by the Auditor General.
My hon. friend should know that the spirit of the policies was followed in the way that we went about handing out the contracts because of the importance we felt of getting on with the job and dealing with the problems we are addressing, problems countries around the world are facing. It is because we were anxious to get out there that we took the action we did.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Public Works.
Despite the Auditor General's previous reports which indicate that lease/purchase agreements is a very costly method of acquiring public buildings, how can this tired old government justify entering into a 25-year lease agreement in 1991 for the Louis St. Laurent building in Hull?

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for a number of reasons.
On the contrary, this government very energetically pursued the request of DND to provide some long-term stable space for the department. We acquired some valuable additional assets, converted them into a lease/ purchase agreement, avoided moving expenses and, perhaps more important, preserved 40,000 square metres of space on the Outaouais side which helped to preserve the important proportion of space traditionally allocated on both sides of the river.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the same minister.
We know that the Department of National Defence will no longer need the Louis-Saint-Laurent building after only 10 years of a 25-year lease contract with a purchase option.
We know that this building has cost private industry $41.5 million and that, according to very conservative figures, taxpayers will probably have paid more than $270 million at the end of the contract.

November 24, 1992
Oral Questions
How can this exhausted government which refuses to follow the advice of the Auditor General justify this gargantuan squandering of public funds?

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, over the term of this lease/purchase agreement there will be ample opportunity because of the turnovers that Public Works and this government require to utilize that building fully.
Although at the time the timeframe that DND required it may not have been apparent, it will be fully utilized and will present good value for the money when the analysis is completed.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
Today the Auditor General reported on the procurement policies of the Department of National Defence. He used these words among others: defective, cumbersome, ineffective, very expensive, wasted costs amounting to several billions of dollars, and equipment exceeding existing or planned capabilities elsewhere in the world.
Will the Prime Minister at least take the first two steps necessary to bring the department's spending under control: freeze the $4.4 billion helicopter program and fire the Minister of National Defence?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can assure the member we have everything to fire in the department.

I read the Auditor General's report a few hours ago and I found it very interesting on the whole. Most of the analyses were made in co-operation with and with the collaboration of the Department of National Defence and over the last few months we have modified a number of our policies in accordance with the Auditor General's suggestions.

Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General's report says that these programs and problems are continuing.
The report additionally says that virtually all projects examined experience schedule delays and cost overruns. Spare costs exceed 50 per cent of alternative costs. There are severe deficiencies in the naval reserve and militia and substantial deficiencies in the air reserve, programs which cost over three-quarters of a billion dollars.
Will the government concede that Department of National Defence spending is completely out of control?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Minister of National Defence
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is clear that the answer to that question is a definite no. The department must take into account the constantly evolving international situation, it must consider the fact that most of these major projects take 10, even 15 years between the time of their inception and the delivery of the products to the department. We are very aware of the importance of the public funds invested in these projects and that is why we will abide by the Auditor General's suggestions and streamline some of our procedures.

Mr. Speaker, in his report, the Auditor General says that the annual deficit and the debt are of great concern to Canadians. In the last budget, the forecast for the deficit was less than $28 billion and it has now reached $35 billion.
Why will the Minister of Finance not accept the Auditor General's recommendation and recognize that the Tory government must give Parliament and Canadian taxpayers more precise information on the debt and the deficit and more realistic comparisons between anticipated results and the actual figures?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I genuinely appreciate the comments of the Auditor General because he recognizes the importance of controlling the deficit and dealing with the structural debt problems. I also appreciate the fact he has indicated that we should be taking more steps to communicate these to the Canadian public.
I find that most encouraging and I find the hon. member's question most encouraging, because day in and day out we get criticized from opposition members for advertising and for spending money on the dissemination of information.
November 24, 1992

Things such as Where Your Tax Dollars Go is something that is available to all Canadians. We try to send out this kind of information on a monthly and quarterly basis.
If the hon. member's question is in the form of a representation to do more of that, I will take that under serious advisement.

Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General states in his annual report that the government has given absolutely no indication that it intends to publish the performance score card he asked for last year on its action plan to reduce the deficit. That action plan incidentally has seen the predicted deficit jump from $28 billion to $35 billion.
Is it because the Minister of Finance is too embarrassed to report accurately on his government's performance with respect to its eight-year stewardship, or is it just that the Tories do not understand what kind of damage they have inflicted on the Canadian economy as a result of their policies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I will have an action plan to propose to the House of Commons and the people of Canada on December 2. I hope the hon. member will stand in his place and support us.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
According to the Auditor General, Canada's international debt exposure to regional development banks, plus this government's debt forgiveness last year to Poland and Egypt, comprised billions of dollars of Canadian undisclosed debt. Why is this tired old government hiding its real and total indebtedness from the Canadian people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, speaking of a tired old government, we have a tired old opposition party over there, the Liberal Party, that has not had a new policy idea since the seventies.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
As the hon. member knows, Canada extends credit to a number of sovereign states for many reasons: to promote Canadian exports, to support
Oral Questions
our foreign policy objectives and to aid in the economic development of less developed countries.
The government remains of the view that the principle of the ultimate collectability of these sovereign loans is the basis upon which we participate in the Paris Club, a group of creditor countries. It is in that forum that we deal with these particular issues because there are other countries involved in precisely the same activity and we work at that in a collective manner.

Mr. Speaker, if the minister would look at the report he would see that the Auditor General and this government-to-be do not agree.
My supplementary question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs. Canada pays more per capita to international development banks than any other nation despite the fact that full audits are not available.
We know the good track record of non-government organizations in alleviating global poverty and promoting sustainable development. We question the performance of international development banks.
Will the Secretary of State for External Affairs guarantee no further cutbacks to NGO programs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Landry (Minister for External Relations and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)):
speakerposition: Minister for External Relations; Minister responsible for La Francophonie; Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General's chapter on regional development banks points to a very complex aspect of our international co-operation activities. Nevertheless, I think that these regional development banks play a very important role in the support they give developing countries.
Of course, our program is very varied and supports different activities of our development partners for the benefit of the countries concerned. These partners may be NGOs, which my colleague just mentioned, the private sector, institutions and also regional development banks which we think play a very important role.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration. Our constitutional proposals included transferring labour force training to the provinces. Today,

November 24, 1992
Oral Questions
because Canadians said no in the referendum, we seem to be saying to them with some bitterness, "No, too bad. You should have said yes".
Nevertheless, since eliminating overlap could save $250 to $300 million and the transfer could be done through an administrative agreement on manpower training, does he not find that our attitude toward Quebec seems to be intransigent, since there is consensus on this issue in our province?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is not with bitterness but rather fully aware of the people's verdict on the provisions of the Charlottetown accord that we will deal with the request to transfer jurisdiction or authority.
The problem now is that it is crucial for the competitiveness of the Canadian economy to have a trained labour force. Surely within the present constitutional framework a way can be found with the provinces and the private sector to avoid duplication and ensure that taxpayers and Canadians who need training benefit from a coherent, well-co-ordinated program. That is the challenge before all of us parliamentarians. In January, I intend to call Canada's ministers of employment and immigration together to see how we can better co-ordinate our activities so that Quebec workers end up benefiting from these training programs.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Last Thursday the Bank of Canada raised its interest rates by almost 1 per cent, but the value of the Canadian dollar still fell. Clearly speculators do not believe that the government is going to keep interest rates so high when the Canadian economy is in such bad shape. Today the bank rate has gone up almost another full percentage point.
What strategy does this government think it is following? Does the minister not realize that keeping interest rates lower and letting the dollar find its own level would be far healthier for the Canadian economy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, financial markets internationally have been very volatile over the last month or so. In so far as Canada is concerned, it has put upward pressure on interest rates and downward pressure on the value of the dollar.
I am concerned about this volatility and I am concerned about the effect that it will have on economic recovery, but I reiterate the point that I have made on previous occasions: there is international uncertainty and volatility. I note that today the European banks have had to raise their interest rates in Ireland, Spain, Portugal, Norway and Greece.
The hon. member is aware of the exchange volatility in the U.K., France and other countries. There also appears to be an element of speculation in recent financial market developments.
I want to assure the hon. member and the country that the government is not changing its economic policy stance. We are committed to the principle of price stability. We are committed to the principle of fiscal consolidation and we are committed to the principle of economic restructuring. We will continue to follow those policies.

Mr. Speaker, the key question is whether this government is committed to a policy of full employment and economic expansion like the United States government that has just been elected seems to be.
The minister should be aware that a reduction of three percentage points in Canadian interest rates on a sustained basis means 125,000 new jobs. It means the difference between thousands of small businesses surviving or collapsing.
Will this government place these new jobs and the survival of these small businesses first and stop trying to maintain the value of the dollar by pushing up interest rates?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, that is a very interesting proposal. I am rather attracted to the hon. member's observation that he is attracted to the Clinton policy initiatives.

November 24, 1992

Oral Questions
President-elect Clinton is very much in favour of the free trade agreement because he thinks it is good for Canada and for the United States. President-elect Clinton is very much in favour of the North American free trade agreement because he thinks it is good for jobs in Canada, the United States and Mexico. Does that mean the hon. member is going to support that as well?
The hon. member knows better. You cannot just simply dial a phone and reduce interest rates by 3 per cent. That is being naive.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:

This is further to the question I directed to the Minister of Labour on November 17, 1992, concerning inclusion in the Canada Labour Code of the preventive withdrawal of pregnant workers. The answer I received was that cabinet had approved the bill in question and the minister intended to table the bill in the very near future.
Can the minister let the House know today when this bill, which is extremely important for all Canadian women, will be placed on the legislative agenda for consideration at the earliest possible opportunity in the House of Commons?

speakerposition: Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member pointed out, my cabinet colleagues have agreed in principle with this very important bill which deals with the redeployment of pregnant women.
I can assure the hon. member and other members of this House that the government intends to table this bill in the near future. I want to congratulate the hon. member on the interest he has shown in this matter.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Defence. The Auditor General this morning listed case after case where the management of capital projects by DND has been, in his words, ineffective. Yet this tired old government and this tired old minister have kept in place exactly the same management procedures for the production of the EH-101 helicopter.
Why has the minister not put in place new management procedures for the EH-101 helicopter, as recommended by the Auditor General, so as to save the Canadian taxpayer billions of dollars?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):

In this report the Auditor General reveals that the difficulties observed in the management of defence programs is related to problems generated early in the project life cycle during project initiation.
Given the magnitude of the EH-101 helicopter program, $4.5 billion, the third largest program for the government ever, will the minister have the Auditor General review the program at this stage of its life cycle?

November 24, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Minister of National Defence

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport. In his statement this morning, the Minister of Transport outlined the government funding that was sought by Canadian Airlines in order to complete its transaction with its employees and American Airlines.
My question is this. Is the giving of the loan guarantees which were sought by Canadian still under consideration by the government or is the $50 million offered today the only and final assistance to be given by this government to Canadian Airlines?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I outlined in my statement this morning the hurdles that were in the way for the Government of Canada to be able to intervene in this matter.
I have said many times in the past that we were very impressed by the desire of the 15,000 or 16,000 employees of Canadian Airlines to save their airline. It is for that reason we came to the table. We have put our proposal on the table and it has been accepted. Both the company and the employees are already saying that they are very satisfied with the government's response to their request.

Mr. Speaker, I have no doubt the employees are pleased to receive any assistance they can get from the government. However, my question was a very specific one.
The minister outlined the conditions that were sought by Canadian Airlines in the proposal that was put to the government last week. The minister's statement reveals a willingness to contribute some money but does not respond to the loan guarantees that were requested.
Will the government consider giving the loan guarantees that were sought in order to complete the American Airlines transaction, or is this the last and final offer of assistance this government is prepared to make to Canadian Airlines?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the obvious conclusion is that the hon. member did not really read the statement I made in the House this morning. I explained that responding to the proposal in its present form would expose both Canadian taxpayers and the employees themselves to losing their investment outright because we do not control one of the fundamental conditions of this proposal, which is that PWA is to leave the Gemini system altogether before the other conditions set by American Airlines can come into play. An affirmative response in this respect would mean putting considerable amounts of taxpayers' money at risk, as well as the personal contributions of employees.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the minister of fisheries about some tired old clam beds in my riding.
I have heard from over 500 constituents along the Bay of Fundy shore and the Northumberland Strait shore through meetings, letters and petitions requesting that the government establish conservation measures to protect the clam stocks along these shores.
I would like the minister to tell us if under section 43 of the Fisheries Act the department can establish these conservation measures, and will it?

November 24, 1992

licensed and will also deal with persons fishing clams recreationally.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs. It concerns the plight of Christine Lamont and David Spencer, who are held in Brazilian prisons on 28-year jail sentences.
Last week the House of Commons justice committee again strongly and unanimously urged the minister to request the expulsion of Chris and David from Brazil, noting that in addition to the earlier miscarriages of justice they had documented, their lives are now threatened because of violence in Brazilian jails.
My question for the minister is very straightforward. How much longer is she determined to wait, how much longer must the lives of Christine and David be at risk before this minister finally listens to the voices of the justice committee and thousands of Canadians and seeks their expulsion from Brazil?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think that it is important to repeat once again that the process of expulsion in Brazil is neither automatic nor easy and in fact it would be unprecedented in modern times, particularly given the legal process that is going on at the moment.
I am sure the hon. member will be glad to know, because of representations on behalf of the Government of Canada, we have been able to obtain some information about the state of the process that is going on at the moment. The case is under active consideration in Brasilia. The appeals are before federal judges. They have had advice from the Attorney General.
We are optimistic that these cases will be heard in the very short term and we will have some answers on the length of the sentences about which we understand the Attorney General of Brazil has stated he would like to see some differentiation.
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, through you to the same minister. David Spencer in a letter from prison in Brazil said: "The important thing for fair-minded souls in Canada to understand is to say we are waiting for local remedies to be exhausted is to say we will do nothing".
In view of the fact that the lawyers for both Christine and David in Brazil and Canada have made it very clear that the process of appeals and transfer could take many more months, if not years, I want to ask this minister specifically why is she continuing to wait? How much longer will she wait before she finally acts on the unanimous report of the justice committee, before she finally recognizes that their lives are at risk because of the violence in Brazil? How much longer will this minister continue to fail to live up to her responsibilities as minister on behalf of these Canadian citizens?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think that I and the people in the embassy have more than lived up to our responsibilities with regard to Mr. Spencer and Miss Lamont.
I should point out that the lawyers for Mr. Spencer and Miss Lamont do not have anyone in Brasilia, whereas the embassy does have people there. They are very close to the appeal process that is going on and is under very active consideration in Brasilia right now. We believe and have every reason to believe that our information is correct.
