speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
At the suspension of the debate the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood had eight minutes remaining.

November 24, 1992
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, as I was saying before Question Period began, we on this side of the House were disturbed by the fact that all of the amendments put forward by our critics in committee were rejected by the government side of the House.
A lot of those recommendations were as a result of listening to many experts from across the country, as well as the experience we have had as members of Parliament. Constituents would come to us from time to time on highly sensitive issues or on issues and problems that could not be addressed by the Public Service or situations where the Public Service, in the opinion of our constituents, was not really giving a fair judgment or a fair evaluation.
As I have said, the rejection by the government of all of our recommendations is not really working in the true spirit of amending the bill in a constructive way.
This is a very complex bill. I have not read every line of this bill, but I want to refer to the section we have to deal with on a regular basis in our constituency offices. That has to do with the section relating to the minister's ability to suspend the normal process and let people come to our country by way of a ministerial permit. Quite often the minister will act on the advice and information presented by a member of Parliament.
There have been many, many times in the last four years where the minister of immigration, including ministers previous to our current minister, the hon. member for St. Paul's, when minister's permits were approved for those people whose names were given to the minister by members of Parliament.
What concerns me about this bill is the fact that we are delegating more responsibility to the front line officials which would create a situation in which a member of Parliament would not be in a position to even put forward a request for a minister's permit on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
I have known of many examples where officials in the department have either not reviewed all of the information in their possession or even if they did have the whole file at times their judgment was debatable. Hence, as members of Parliament we would present this to the
minister's office and often we could get that decision reversed. This bill works against the ability of members of Parliament, especially those in urban areas, to do their job properly and effectively.
There is no mention and no recognition in this bill for members of Parliament to have any special support or ability to appeal on behalf of those people who have been rejected by senior officials.
I notice that section 121 states:
The Minister or the Deputy Minister, as the case may be, may authorize such persons employed in the public service of Canada as the Minister or Deputy Minister deems proper to exercise any of the powers and perform any of the duties and functions that maybe or are required to be exercised or performed by the Minister or Deputy Minister, as the case may be, under this Act or the regulations, other than the powers, duties and functions referred to-
Then there is a list of subsections. It concerns me that we, as elected members, are often put in situations in which we use our judgment as to whether or not a particular person has the credibility and conditions to be allowed to stay in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds. This section works against our individual ability to try to use our own offices to try to help these people. That is my interpretation of the bill.
I had a situation just three weeks ago in which a senior business person was coming to this country. He had been here three months previously. We worked hard to get him into the country. He came from Bangladesh, but this particular time because he came via New York and he could not speak English, the officials in our immigration section in New York wanted to turn him away.
I called as the member of Parliament appealing to let the man in. Business meetings were already arranged. I finally had to write a formal letter guaranteeing that if I did not make sure this person returned, I would give up my seat. That was the only way I could get this person into the country. In other words, the immigration officials were not respecting the judgment and the information we had on our end and they were quite cocky about it.
Nothing in this bill shows any respect for the individual judgment of the representations being made in the individual offices of MPs. I continue to voice my objection to that particular aspect of the bill.
November 24, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have been anxious to respond to my friend from Broadview-Greenwood. There are two points in particular to which I would like to respond.
I will come back to the question of the role of the member of Parliament as protected by the legislation or inferred by the legislation in helping determine immigration cases. I think that is something we want to discuss in this House as a principle, particularly as we look at long lines of people who want to have immigration dealt with either through family unification or other processes.
The comment my colleague has made a number of times is that the government has rejected all opposition amendments. I want to point out first of all that the legislative committee in sitting for 61 hours discussed what at one point was about 200 amendments.
As the government brought forward its 70 amendments, some of which were technical, a number of which responded to concerns of witnesses and opposition members, opposition amendments were withdrawn. They were withdrawn with consent by the way which did not need to be given, under which there was no obligation for the government to operate to give that consent in allowing them to be brought back into this House.
It is important to recognize that the minister in his speech and in the process has acknowledged this in terms of amendments. The government has responded in a number of areas setting dates for the tabling of the immigration plan and changing it. With respect to provisions on mobility, terms and conditions, and obligations, changes are provided to that.
There is the whole question of fingerprinting information. There is the question of ability in carrier sanction, protection for medical reasons against public health and safety, offences being offences in Canada and abroad. There is the role of the minister being reinserted in terms of people being returned from Canada and in terms of certification.
We have amended the whole question of detention reviews. The provision concerning senior immigration officers in some areas has been tightened up. Confidentiality of hearings has been tightened up. We have responded to the question of split decisions and the whole area of permanent residence and war criminals.
Government Orders
To say that the government has not accepted any opposition amendments is not correct and I just wanted to correct that. The government spent 61 hours in the legislative committee, its members of the committee, in terms of negotiating with members of the opposition addressing their concerns. Government was there and was responsive.
I want to respond to the question of the role of the member of Parliament with the minister. First of all, the government has made it very clear that the question of the humanitarian and compassionate grounds process is not visible and therefore is not properly accessible. Gordon Fairweather has been asked to design regulations and consult on how to make that process accessible because that is the place my colleague and I access the system for refugees.
If my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood is suggesting that as members of Parliament we should have a priority position in terms of our ability to affect the immigration procedure I do not think he would find support for this. Thousands of our constituents-more his than mine-have been waiting for years to have the system bring people into this country to reunite families. If he is suggesting that we should have a system, not necessarily in a priority, but a system more capable of responding to us and that the role of political interference in the system should be enhanced, I do not think there would be support for that across the country.
Yes, as representatives of the people we do have a responsibility to make the case. But to expect that we would have a role that would influence the system to benefit one over the other is something we should be very cautious of, particularly in the use of minister's permits. I would love to hear his comment on exactly that point.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the member's response to the point of amendments. I was quite specific when I mentioned that my colleague from Notre-Dame-de-Grace had specific amendments which were rejected last night one by one. Not one of them would have hurt any aspect of this bill. Every one of them would have improved it. That is the point I was making, that there was a rejection of an honest attempt to improve the bill.

Government Orders
I want to go back to the point about the role of members of Parliament. I am not talking about political interference, but when I have a woman in my constituency office who has been a victim of violence, when she shows me a file that states a senior official wants to deport her and put her back into a situation where her life is in danger, as a member of Parliament I should be able to assess that crisis situation. I can tell you that it was not the first letter, the second letter or the third letter that brought results, it was when the member for Trinity-Spadina, the member from Hyde Park and myself-and we all know the case that we are talking about-did a full frontal assault on the government that we got some action.
That was just one case. I can tell you, and I say this with respect, in downtown Toronto we have a lot of immigration problems. We have situations where there are family trust opportunities, where people have a business. They expand and start another one and want to bring in a relative from another country. It all looks legitimate to me, but they get rejected by the officials. As a member of Parliament, what the heck are we here for if we are not to take those cases where people feel they are not getting proper justice from the Public Service?
I have a situation right now where I have written to the ambassador in South Africa about a young married couple, the Korolia family. The daughter is Canadian and married to a South African gentleman. She is pregnant. The father who is back here runs a successful business. He has offered him a job so the family can be reunited but the department has rejected giving him a work permit.
When that person comes in my door and asks for help, are you telling me I should say: "I am sorry, I cannot help you. Go and deal with the bureaucracy."

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext: I did not say that.

No, but you started off by saying that I am trying to interfere with the system. You are darned right I am trying to interfere with the system.
If the act is delegating to unelected officials the ability to make judgment calls without any kind of a judicial process, then surely to goodness they should understand that MPs, who are publicly accountable to the people who either support or not support that MP, should be given some respect.
I would suggest to the government that by and large I am with most officials in the Public Service of Canada all the way. I do not care whether it is in business or in government, but every now and again you run into some bad apples. There is nothing more frustrating than when you run into a bad apple when you are trying to represent somebody in a legitimate case. I do not care if you are an MP, you get crisis situations and that is what we are here for.
I just wish there was some kind of directive in this bill, as there is designated some kind of special judgment in respect to officials, that when members of Parliament are representing special cases, fully accountable, that they be properly heard on behalf of their constituents. I do not think the member for St. John's East really objects to that.

Mr. Speaker, I would certainly like to identify with the remarks of the member for Broadview-Greenwood.
On the issue of a member of Parliament having access to that process, the process is so basically outrageous and unfair that there needs to be some public representation made to the minister's office.
I just did a quick consultation with several of my colleagues and I cannot identify with the remarks of the hon. member when he said that the minister's office deals in a fair and equitable way with interventions from members of Parliament. I would use the example of many Indo-Canadians of the Sikh persuasion who live in the area that I represent. Parents are trying to bring children into the country. It takes years and often fails.
In the case of two brothers, the mother had gone to India. As tradition requires she had gone to arrange a marriage of the one who had become engaged. The majority of the family were all Canadians. The other brother gave up because of the outrageous time period. He wound up marrying the woman in India and the individual who became engaged is still waiting to have that ceremony conducted in Canada.
A Sikh member of our community, a Canadian citizen, and his wife had gone back to India. He tried to come back to visit his family, the majority of whom are British Columbians and Canadians. The immigration department refuses him a visitor's visa. It says: "You cannot visit. We think you are going to try and bring your wife
November 24, 1992

into Canada to stay here". They had been long-time residents.
This process is so outrageous, it stinks so badly that it needs the intervention of members of Parliament to make sure there is fair play and justice. There ought to be a visa office in the Punjab. It is so overdue just on family unification and basic decency that this government ought to be putting that visa office in.

Mr. Speaker, my response to the member will be short.
I have a situation in my riding today and I am almost embarrassed to admit that I cannot do anything about it.
A Greek family has been here for 11 years. He got bad advice on his landing papers. He has two children, nine and eleven years old. Three weeks ago, after many representations from my office, the government deported the mother and family. Now the kids are living as wards of the state. When we have an immigration system that is acting that way and rejecting solid political advice, there is something wrong with it.
Mr. Speaker, before I begin, I would like to indicate that I am splitting my time with the member for Surrey-White Rock-South Langley, five minutes and five minutes.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member has 10 minutes maximum with five minutes questions or comments.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to debate a topic of such importance to the future of our immigration program.
The objectives of Bill C-86, the reunification of families, the protection of refugees and the promotion of economic growth were in fact in danger of being seriously compromised by the system's increasing inability to handle the convergence of pressures and by the related erosion of confidence Canadians were expressing toward our immigration programs and objectives.
In this climate, the government understood from the outset the urgent need for a constructive and open examination of the methods, processes and criteria we use to select and bring people to Canada. We understood as well that this examination had to involve as many Canadians as possible. That is why the government
Government Orders
undertook the most broadly-based and yet focused consultative and educational immigration strategy in Canadian history.
These open-ended consultations dealt with such critical issues as the number of immigrants we would accept over a five-year period to meet our domestic needs and international goals; the speed with which we should bring immigrants to Canada in the context of our ability as a nation to handle the increase and the best way to integrate newcomers into our society.
As well, the past eight years have seen other significant developments, including a gradual and controlled increase in over-all immigration levels, a parallel expansion of the services essential to integrating new Canadians into our way of life and a long-overdue overhaul of our refugee determination system in response to historically unprecedented pressures on the program.
These amendments clearly provide Canada with the tools to manage change in the 1990s. A common thread running through all the consultations, deliberations and debate on Bill C-86 has been an acknowledgement of the need to manage our immigration program more effectively, with greater fairness and with greater relevance to the needs of Canada as a whole. This is what Bill C-86, as now proposed, sets out to accomplish. Specifically, the proposed amendments offer a rational, workable formula to manage change in three distinct but interrelated areas of immigration policy.
First, Bill C-86 provides the means to further streamline our refugee determination system to ensure that fair decisions are rendered and rendered quickly.
Second, Bill C-86 would better protect Canadian society by tightening enforcement and control measures to defend the integrity of the system and protect the public from those who would abuse our programs or break our laws.
Third, under these amendments we could select effectively those who come to Canada through improved management of the categories and numbers of immigrants, thus ensuring that immigration continues to contribute to our social development and economic prosperity.
If I may, I would like to touch very briefly on each of these three crucial areas.

November 24, 1992
Government Orders
I believe everyone here today and most Canadians understand the need to streamline our refugee determination system. Quite simply, the time required to process claims and make decisions is still too long and that is not fair to legitimate claimants.
The speed with which we can remove rejected claimants remains slow and that erodes the effectiveness of the system. The consequence of all the delay is further pressure on costly support programs and that certainly is not fair to taxpayers.
The co-ordinated changes proposed in this bill will serve to create a more workable, clear-cut and streamlined refugee determination system. These changes include, among others, the elimination of the first level or credible basis hearing which was proving ineffective, improvements at the immigration and refugee board level to accelerate processing, cuts to administrative costs to allow genuine refugees to more quickly become part of the community, new procedures to expedite the landing of convention refugees with cuts of up to six months in the waiting time for landed status, and more timely, effective and fair removal procedures in cases where claims have been rejected.
The impact of these changes, including faster family reunification and a more efficient decision-making process will only enhance the special position Canada has in the world for its work on behalf of refugees. Complementing these changes, Bill C-86 proposes measures to better protect our immigration system from abuse.
At our borders we will give immigration staff the power to search individuals and to seize documents and vehicles used in smuggling operations. We will expand the authority of our immigration officers to fingerprint and photograph refugee claimants and increase the penalties for people caught smuggling. The net result of these efforts will be to more clearly distinguish between those who should benefit from Canada's generosity and those who should not.
Clearly, in a decade that promises continuing international volatility, large-scale movements of people and economic uncertainty, the ability to more effectively manage our immigration system is a priority. The changes Bill C-86 proposes will ensure that our immigration program can deal with change while fulfilling its time-honoured role as a contributor to national growth and prosperity.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have taken part in debates like this over the years. In 1975 I was a member of the green paper committee to examine the total reorganization of immigration legislation at that time. It was a major project because it had not been done for many years. The government of the day did a thorough job issuing study papers and providing background papers on the subject of immigration.
I also worked on this matter in 1987. I was the parliamentary secretary at the time when we were dealing with Bill C-55 and Bill C-84 and now as a member of the committee that dealt with this matter on Bill C-86.
I have had some continuity on the subject and I would like to offer some of my observations. As I say, in 1975 when we were debating this legislation and it came into effect in 1978, one of the fundamental tenets of that legislation was the determination on the part of the then Liberal government-and I agreed with its determination-that Canada is a sovereign country and coming to Canada is a privilege and not a right and that we as Canadians need to preserve the authority of our sovereignty.
In that mix we should never forget our commitment historically and to the present and contemporary days to compassion for those who have not had the advantages that we have today and to preserve those. In those days we designed refugee legislation that was to accommodate a flow of 300 refugees a year. That was about 1977, 1978.
The House will remember what happened when the boat people and their trauma came to our attention and Canada opened its gates. After that the idea of refugees took a dramatic turn in our consciousness in Canada. We have continuously wanted to maintain that posture of compassion and understanding, openness and hospitality to those people who are genuinely in need.
When we redraft legislation we have also to take a look at the process. The government drafts legislation on the basis of the information it has, on the basis of the agreement of its caucus. It drafts the legislation and then it is exposed to the opposition. The opposition does what it ought to do as good opposition parties do. It exercises its role in examining and opposing those sections that it
November 24, 1992

believes are wrong. Any good opposition will do that and it will do it with all of the energy it possesses.
To give maximum exposure, to make sure that process works, we move into a committee system and, to speak frankly to it, in most cases the witnesses who come before the committee are brought there by and large, not exclusively, by members of the opposition. That is fine.
It is only as you sharpen the examination by people who oppose certain sections that you refine a bill. If everybody agrees you get very little refinement. I applaud that system.
Members of the opposition in this bill did an excellent piece of work. I commend the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace and the member for Spadina with whom I sat in committee who were thorough and persistent and who put forward amendments. They did very good work and I enjoyed working with them.
They opposed certain sections. They did not always oppose and that is what I appreciated about their work. They opposed where they thought they should oppose and agreed with those sections they thought were positive in their view.
If the member for Edmonton will be quiet for a minute I will carry on.
Save us the cliches.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
I have learned a few from you.
The committee did its work but in order to bring these witnesses we brought witnesses who opposed but what struck me in going through these processes, through these several stages that I have seen in my time here in Parliament, was that the same witnesses appeared several times and said the same thing each time, even though we were adjusting previous legislation.
For example, here is what Mark Schelew of Amnesty International said in 1987 when we were debating Bill C-55: "It is an about-face on Canada's humanitarian record that may place people fleeing persecution in jeopardy".
In 1992 when we were debating revisions to Bill C-55 he said: "We strongly urge you to stick to the status quo".
Government Orders
What made the difference? In 1987 he opposes Bill C-55 and in 1992 he supports Bill C-55 and he says: "Do not change it. Keep it where it is. Do not do what you are going to do now in terms of adjustments".
I suggest that if we are going to have witnesses, they ought to be credible. To be credible, one ought to say something consistently. If one believes it in 1987, one ought to believe it in 1992, unless something has changed and it did. Reality set in.
While he condemned it in 1987 as being the end of compassion, he saw that in the intervening years between 1987 and 1992 the bill actually worked, that the refugees did come, that they had access, that the system was operating and that refugees were lining up to come to our shores. It was not exactly what he had thought it would be in 1987.
The Canadian Bar Association came before us this time, members like Lome Waldman of immigration fame. The Canadian Bar Association says the system is working. It says it in 1992 and Bill C-55 has done all right. Lome Waldman does not always agree with that and Lome Waldman in 1987, when he was opposing Bill C-55, said: "The long-term aim of the immigration department is to eliminate all refugee claims within Canada. The government has spent millions of dollars and innumerable hours consulting on this problem and everybody's recommendations have been ignored altogether".
It has not been so. Since when have we turned off the taps regarding the refugee flow? What Lome Waldman said in 1987 did not happen in the ensuing years. There is an old adage that if a prophet prophesizes and it does not come true, you ought to get rid of the prophet, at least the prophet's standing.
We had Gunter Plaut appear in 1987. He said: "If C-55 would have been applied to me when I was coming to Canada, I would not have been allowed into Canada. In 1992,1 have read the bill several times and sometimes it occurred to me that it would be easier if the clock were turned back to admit Nazis to this country, as we have done in some profusion, than to admit those they persecuted".

Government Orders
In 1987 he says not to do C-55 and in 1992 says that it would be easier for Nazis to come in than for Jews. Can we accept the credibility of witnesses who say things like that, first of all that are not accurate and second that do not happen? As I say, the old adage is if the prophet prophesizes and it does not happen, maybe we ought to examine his prophecy status.
More than that, I want to point out that for all of the doom and gloom that has been sent our way regarding Canada's position on this issue, it has not come to pass. I point out that in 1987 the member for Vancouver- Kingsway at that time said this is a government that has cut back on immigration. When we came into office the flow was 89,000 and today it is 225,000 and he says it has been cut back.
When we want witnesses we ask them to be credible. To be credible they have to say things that are consistent. The fact is that Bill C-86 will strengthen our immigration system, it will keep out those people who are not interested in the welfare of Canada. I speak specifically to section 19(l)(k); people who are not interested in Canada's welfare but have other ulterior reasons for coming here. It consolidates Canada's sovereignty.
I confirm what the Liberal government passed in 1975, that Canada is a sovereign country. It is a privilege to come to this country. We want to extend that privilege to as many people as possible, to those who have the welfare of Canada at heart.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for Surrey-White Rock-South Langley for his comments which were mostly accurate, especially the parts that were so favourable to the opposition members now and the opposition members when he was in opposition.
However, I would ask him if he would acknowledge two points that he did not make but that were relevant. When people condemned Bill C-55-this was one of the major objects of condemnation-it had the principle of safe third country in it. When the witnesses came before us, that safe third country principle had not been amended.
It was partly amended within the committee and I believe the member will remember the day I came over to ask whether the word "any" could be introduced
there. I am told that word has made it a great deal better. I do not know whether the member thinks so.
What I am pointing out is that the condemnation was expressed before the amendments. Second, it was expressed before the minister of the time decided not to proclaim that safe third country section of the bill so that all the people who might have been sent away under the provisions of that were not sent away. They were allowed to have their claim examined.
Is it not true that the present bill restricts the safe third country provision further as it does not include the caution that was included five years ago; namely, that the person shall not be sent back there by the IRB if he or she has a well-founded fear of persecution in the country where they had refuge?
Those are two circumstances that the hon. member did not mention but that considerably changed the minds of some of the people I know who were concerned with refugee law and I am wondering if he would comment on those.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
I would simply say to the member from Spadina that there are a lot of things about the bills that I did not mention, both Bill C-55 and Bill C-86.
I would say also that I would agree with him that he has proposed amendments that have perfected the legislation, and I think members of the department would agree. I do not say this with any sense of gratuity or anything else. I say it and I have said it to him privately that what he has done in committee has been very good work.
When he says that he included the word "any", I take his word for it. I believe he has made some good suggestions to the legislation.
With your help.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Enough of the accolades now, right Dan? With regard to the safe third country concept, the difficulty with discussing this is that we lock ourselves into time periods. Safe third country was a concept which in 1987 and 1988 had an impact that it does not have today. The world has changed.
Tike a look at the iron curtain, take a look at what is happening in Latin America and in all other places in the world that have undergone very large changes. I subscribe to the safe third country concept because underlying the safe third country concept is the doctrine of
November 24, 1992

refoulement on which the United Nations has spoken very straight forwardly and very eloquently.
I might say parenthetically that the Canadian representative of the UNHCR has endorsed this legislation, as the member will agree. The doctrine of refoulement is at the heart of what that convention is about and safe third country incorporates that concept so that refugees who had a genuine fear of being brought back into the area of persecution from which they had come should not be and would not be sent back.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make some general comments about the legislation before us today and about the operation of immigration facilities in particular.
It is interesting that over the years it has been one of the most difficult agencies for people to deal with. It also is one of the most poignant and heart-rending experiences when in a constituency office you are dealing on a regular basis with people who have come to Canada, set up homes, built businesses, got jobs and contributed to this country and then they attempt to reunite their families by bringing them to Canada.
Over the term I have been here, the government has professed to put family reunification up as a priority. I for one have to say that this is not a priority the way it is working when there are long, long separations between family members, between parents and children. When that occurs, it is very sad indeed. The first item is the problems that are as a result of enormous bureaucratic red tape. This is an agency that is absolutely overwhelmed. The resources to handle these cases in an expeditious manner are not in place and it becomes very difficult to tolerate. Tempers flare and there is a kind of sadness that pervades the entire process.
I have been working with a family on the sunshine coast for going on eight years where there has been an attempt to reunite a mother with her two children. Of course, as time goes on the children qualify at one point and they do not qualify at another. There are extensive delays. That occurs in the Philippines. There definitely needs to be some additional resources, especially applied to family reunification.
Government Orders
The most difficult area I have found is working with Indo-Canadians, Sikhs who live on the west coast of Canada, immigrated to this country, made a tremendous contribution in terms of the work and to the community where they live. The people are hard-working, industrious, well thought of. They try to bring children into this country and there is just an enormous period of time before they are able to effect those reunifications.
In a lot of cases some minor medical ailment prevents the reunification altogether or there is a situation where the process drags on so long that because of the age of the child, the reunification cannot be carried out.
The member for Broadview-Greenwood mentioned an outrageous situation of an Indo-Canadian and his wife who came from the Punjab many, many years ago. He had become a citizen of Canada and his wife had not. They had raised their children in Canada and they are all Canadians. He went back to India after he retired. He wanted to pay a visit to his children in Canada and he was denied the opportunity. He could not even get a visa. The argument by some immigration officer who handled the case was: "What if he tries to stay in Canada. He is a Canadian and if he tries to leave his wife in India, that would be an outrageous thing". Such thoughtless and inhumanitarian approaches to immigration outrage everyone who touches that case. It is almost an argument that the motivation is racism that is putting those decisions in place. It goes on and on and on. There are many, many cases in a similar vain. It causes enormous frustration.
When you are dealing with the minister's office you invariably wind up with the folks for immigration who have been assigned to that office. I am absolutely assured that they handle what they can but they are overwhelmed by the task.
This is especially true for those that have been assigned to handle the work of 290-odd members of Parliament whose constituents are constantly raising these kinds of concerns. In that process of being overwhelmed, the file falls down and then it goes to a busy immigration office somewhere and it falls down. Months

November 24, 1992
Government Orders
and months go by before you hear back. Usually it involves another process and more months go by.
It is an extremely frustrating situation for members of Parliament and for the families involved. These are not the marginal cases where there really is some question or doubt. These are legitimate family members who are known in the community, whose children are known and established in another area and it is simply a push for the reunification of that family.
For example, we have had situations with Chilean refugees where we could not make no headway. At that time it was not the Conservative government that was in power. It was a Liberal government. The minister at that time was the member for Winnipeg South Centre. The office was as difficult if not more difficult to deal with when the Liberals were in power. I guess it is probably the same thing; understaffed, no resources and maybe a difference in attitude if it is an Indo-Canadian family rather than another family that is trying for unification.
I recall when the member for Winnipeg South Centre was the minister of immigration how outraged the community of Campbell River in British Columbia was. There was a longstanding Chilean family who had come to Canada because of the tremendous conflict in Chile. They had established themselves working in the mines in this country and eventually in western mines outside of Campbell River. It wound up that a brother and his family had to leave Chile. The only place they could get to was Switzerland. They were being threatened with expulsion from Switzerland back to Chile.
It was virtually impossible to get any kind of co-operation from that minister's office or its staff. They came up with 10,000 reasons why that family could not be removed from Chile. One of the Chileans who worked in the mine there actually happened to be a high ranking officer in the police before he left Chile. The father used to be a general in the police force. When this family left Chile, the friends within the police force had said: "Hey, it is time to get out of this. Your union activities are not putting you in a very favourable light here and you are in serious personal danger".
It was a clear indication to him from his friends that they were not going to have a choice. Bad things were
going to happen to that family. That family was out of there in a shot to Switzerland. We fought like crazy. Finally almost every person in the city of Campbell River had to sign a petition and letters and go after the minister to say: "We know these people. We respect them and they are hard working members of our community. Family reunification is a legitimate thing to do". It took forever, but eventually that happened. This is a ridiculous thing to have to do.
These people were in clear personal danger. They were entitled to come as refugees. They had a very large family who were prepared to support them. That individual today is working in that mine as a constructive member of the community, well thought of and held in high regard like the rest of the family and does a tremendous job. Every person in that community who had known that large and extended family knew that would happen. Yet, you could not convince in any kind of a timely way the immigration office to do that.
Certainly the minister is busy. I do not say that in a derogatory way. The staff are overworked, but there are some very useful things that could be done. One of them is to provide more resources in the office so that when a member of Parliament's complaint is brought up, it can be handled in an expeditious way. These are not frivolous complaints.
The second thing is that there really does in some areas of the world need to be additional Canadian immigration or visa offices. The Punjab is an example. You get this crazy situation where it is thousands of miles to travel from the home village to New Delhi. You get to New Delhi. It takes forever to deal with them there. Month after month after month goes by. A medical that was valid at one period of time is no longer valid at another. By the time you get your appointment, your medical is gone. There should be a visa office there where the resources are easily within reach. It would certainly cut down the time if we are serious about reunification and we can put some of these families together that have been waiting for years to get together.
It is a simple matter of resources. I know the government has its program of cutting of government services, user charges for it, but these in many cases are really inhuman when it comes down to the family level.
November 24, 1992

There is a person in Campbell River right now waiting to marry a woman for the last couple of years to whom he is engaged in India. His brother finally gave up the ghost, managed to go to India and marry the woman there without any of his family present but felt that he had to do it. He expects his wife to be in Canada much sooner than the other.
We have got some tremendously difficult situations where families cannot even visit. I have three quick suggestions that could make this a lot easier and a lot more humane. The first one is the government would respond. The government and the minister of immigration's office should respond quickly and effectively to the interventions of members of Parliament. These are not interventions for political purposes or to jump the queue. They are often to try and put parents and children or brothers and sisters back together. Those are the ones that really motivate people to act and make them extremely angry when they do not. Those interventions should be facilitated.
The second thing is that in the minister's office, and I bear no grudge against the people who work there, I think there needs to be more of them so they can move through these interventions more quickly.
If my riding is typical of many other ridings, there seems to be enormous log jams in the Philippines, the Punjab and India as a whole. There really does need to be some resources put into those areas so that visas are issued to parents wanting to visit their children, family members wanting to visit Canadian citizens. They are citizens like any citizen of Canada and yet they are being deprived of the opportunity to visit.
Nobody from Britain has this kind of difficulty. Nobody from Europe or any other area of the earth has this problem. In my experience, these two locations are a critical element.
Another thing seriously concerns me. I would just mention this. As we watch people leaving certain countries of the world, I wonder what is being done. I do not have the information. I raise these simply as flags. Certainly the tension and the difficulties in South Africa are creating enormous news today. We have watched people who we would consider as war criminals being given amnesty. Certainly they are not going to be able to live in their own communities.
I would expect that we are going to get a situation where there is an enormous demand for a place like
Government Orders
Canada to accept these individuals. I would ask what is being done to make sure that we do not accept these people as citizens in this country.
We have the situation in El Salvador in Central America where people who have committed just horrible offences against humanity have been given amnesty by the government which inflicted many of these problems. I wonder what is being done to make sure that we do not get these individuals as citizens in this country. There are indications that process is under way and that has already happened.
With those remarks let us get greater attention paid to family reunification problems within the minister's office. Let us get more resources within those offices and in certain key bottlenecks where family reunification is probably the highest priority in immigration, concerns such as the Punjab and the Philippines. Let us get some resources into that area so that these visits and these reunifications can be obtained, where families can maintain contact and if possible be brought together.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to offer a few comments with respect to people from far away lands who want to visit Canada because you really wonder whether some of these cases are being handled fairly.
I know that immigration people are overworked, there is understaffing, but there are some cases that raise serious questions.
For example, there is a couple who has lived in my riding for more than 20 years. They are of Pakistani origin. They want to bring a nephew to Canada, just to visit for a few weeks in the summer. To secure that visitor's visa they are prepared to post a bond and pay a two-way aeroplane ticket to get the nephew to Winnipeg for a visit.
However there is no way they seem to be able to convince the minister's office and the Canadian authorities in Pakistan to provide that visitor's visa. They point out in a telex to me that the boy is about 15 and only in the ninth grade, although I do not understand the relevance of that. He has never travelled before, and I do not understand the relevance of that. The father of the nephew earns about $230 Canadian a month. I know it is not a lot of money for Canada but over in Pakistan I hear it is not that bad.

Government Orders
The Canadian authorities in Islamabad, Pakistan, point out that given the economic situation, the lack of any previous travel and the commonly held belief that education and future opportunities are better in Canada, the visa officer was not convinced the boy would only be a visitor to Canada. We really have to wonder whether that is fair adjudication. Would they treat a case in this way if the nephew lived in France, Germany, England, Iceland, Sweden or Norway?
This family who lives in my riding is absolutely crushed. They consider themselves to be honourable and honest people. I want to read just a line or two from the letter that the uncle wrote to me: "Indeed myself and my wife love Kashif", the nephew's name, "very dearly and my only wish is to have him visit and experience the adventure of travel and see this country which would be an educational experience for him".
I have dealt with this case for months and I cannot get it moved. I just find there is something wrong. This is a young boy. The uncle and aunt simply want to bring him to Canada for a few weeks. They are prepared to offer anything to underline the fact that they are honest and not trying to play any games.
I feel that as a member of Parliament I have to bring this forward because I just do not think it is fair. It is these kinds of cases that make us wonder what is really going on.
If I could ask a question, I would like to ask the previous speaker whether he feels these cases are common in the area he represents.

Mr. Speaker, I never seem to remember everything that has to go into a speech, but I identify completely with the remarks of the hon. member for Winnipeg-St. James.
Over the 13 years I have been here I do not know how many times we have asked immigration if we could put up a bond and to name the amount; we would get numerous people in the community. We know the families well. They are honest and have integrity. They would never break their word. Yet immigration will not even let a nephew or another relative visit. Many times I have offered to put up a share of that bond and have said: "I know these people. I have known them for 20 years. They are an honest, fine and upstanding group of people. I would trust them with anything". Yet immigration accuses them of conniving and trying to bring people into Canada illegally.
If there were to be another addition it would be a fourth item. If nothing else, let us put up a bond for people who we know and are trusted members of our community. We would put up the bond to endorse that these people are honest and upstanding and that we know they will live up to every letter of the conditions laid down by immigration.
I am very thankful the hon. member raised that, it is such an important point.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to comment on this bill.
We have seen this afternoon a theme developing on the examination of immigration problems in Canada that a disproportionate amount of time in the office of every member of Parliament is focused on the problems of immigration and visas and the heart-wrenching stories from constituents and families trying to bring in then-relatives from other countries. I am hearing echoes in this Chamber from my colleagues on both sides of the House.
The system is not working. What is at stake is Canada's reputation as a humane and caring society. If this government cares for Canada's reputation in that regard, I urge it to reallocate the resources necessary to do the job properly.
I know immigration officials in my constituency are overburdened. I phone them on a regular basis and usually there are more clients in the office than there is staff. If we have anything to do with that, as members of Parliament we have to expose this inadequacy. The morale in the immigration department is at a low ebb, and quite rightly so. They are the ones who are being targeted for all the criticism. It is not the immigration officials; it is the government that should be targeted for criticism.
Canada has a reputation of being a humane and caring nation. We do need immigrants of the kind that has been described in this House, hard working people. We do need a humane policy where families can be reunited even for a visit.
I know of two sisters originally from Sri Lanka who wanted to bring an auntie over who had served as a maid. But if one is not a white Anglo-Saxon, one is suspect; that may not be the reality but that is certainly the perception. As a Canadian member of Parliament, that
November 24, 1992

perception eats at me because that spectre of racism is something that should be fought on all fronts.
I urge this government to reallocate the resources to address the problem in a real way so that Canada's reputation will stop being tainted.

Just to terminate my remarks, I identify as well with the remarks of the previous speaker that the immigration officers in the field are overworked, absolutely overwhelmed by an incredible task. There are many attempts at fraud and attempts to circumvent Canadian law, but in the process of defending that with resources that are too few and too far between a lot of honest cases get thrown to the wolves.
The point raised by the member for Winnipeg-St. James, the possibility of being able to put up a bond to allow somebody to come in on a visit, just a visit to keep family contact together, would be useful. More resources, greater attention to things like family unification items with the pleas of members of Parliament, visa offices and extensions of the visa offices into areas such as the Philippines, the Punjab and other hot spots with a tremendous build-up and where people get lost on the waiting list, would be very useful additions.
It would make honest Canadian citizens a lot happier in a more humane process.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if possible, I should like to split my time with another member of my party. I will not use up the total time allotted in saying a few words on this bill.
I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak. It is a very important piece of legislation, perhaps one of the most important pieces of legislation Parliament will pass. It touches an area that goes deep, to the heart of what we think of ourselves as Canadians and what we are as a nation.
I would start off by saying that this country has had a wonderful history of helping people and welcoming people to its shores. When I think of all the people on earth, I do not know which country has been more open
Government Orders
and more generous over the years than the people of Canada. When there have been problems throughout the world, and there have been many, Canadians have responded.
I remember when I was a teenager there was a brief moment in the history of Czechoslovakia under communism when people were able to escape from that country. I remember many people coming to Canada and being welcomed. They were legitimate refugees escaping a tyrannical system in their own country and Canadians were glad to help them out. There are many examples in our history where people fleeing persecution have been welcomed to Canada's shores.
One thing I believe about Canadians is that they do not want their hospitality abused. They want a system of immigration and refugee determination that works. There is a perception-and I believe it is a correct perception-that the system has been breaking down in this country, that the system has not worked well.
Several years ago Bill C-55 was brought in by this government. It was designed to deal with a number of aspects of Canada's immigration and refugee determination. Many of the same arguments I have heard in this Chamber for the last couple of days I heard then. People were saying that Canada was closing its doors and that Canada was turning away legitimate refugees. I remember at the time having to look at the bill and thinking it was a reasonable response to a very difficult situation. As I say, I do not think my comments cooled down any of the rhetoric on either side.
I remember being at a meeting in Welland with the previous Minister of Employment and Immigration, now the minister of health. There must have been 20 or 30 people outside protesting with signs and handouts that Bill C-55 was going to do a number of terrible things.
All I can say is that did not come to pass. The bill was a reasonable attempt to deal with a very difficult problem. I would suggest that we have the same thing today with this bill. I do not agree with the critics who say that Canada is turning its back on legitimate refugees and that Canadians are setting up a hostile environment for people who want to come to this country.

Government Orders
It is just the opposite. One very frustrating aspect is the widespread belief, and I believe there is basis to it, that the system is breaking down, that the system is being abused. I get this all the time from individuals very close to Canada's refugee determination system. They will tell me that our system is a mess, is not working and is open to abuse.
As a member of Parliament I make considerable use of surveys I take of my constituents. There is always a danger when we send out surveys that we will skewer the result one way or the other. I cover a wide range of topics when I send out surveys, but it came back loud and clear that the concerns of the refugee determination system were not limited to people very close to the system. It is a perception in my case of the people of Niagara Falls and Niagara-on-the-Lake who write to me and return my surveys. They say there is something wrong with a system that takes so long to process refugees or does not move quickly against individuals abusing the system.
That feeling is out there. These are ordinary Canadians, Canadians who I know are a part of the generous and open country I believe is Canada. I believe it is incumbent upon us to respond to those legitimate concerns.
This is why I have said personally to the Minister of Employment and Immigration when I have seen him that he was on the right track and this was an opportunity to put in a place a system that worked better for everybody.
This is a step in the right direction, removing individuals who are blatantly trying to abuse the system. At the same time it is fair to the individuals who are legitimate refugees. One very frustrating fact that every member of Parliament faces are individuals who get caught up in the system and are waiting for years. The huge backlog militates against them trying to get established in Canada and getting on with their lives.
The minister's bill that attempts to try to streamline the process, expedite the process, is in the best interest of everybody. That is one of the reasons I welcome it. I ask hon. members to remember the arguments that were made five or six years ago with Bill C-55, that those things did not come to pass; that in fact Canada did not close its doors in 1986 and we are not going to be doing that here with this bill.
I was talking with the parliamentary secretary just before this about the subject of safe third countries. I live in a border community. This comes into play in my area.
I can say quite frankly after I was elected in 1984 I had a group of individuals come in to see me, wanting to talk about the refugees from Buffalo. I said: "From where?". They said: "The refugees from Buffalo". I know they have trouble paving the roads over there and I know they have some difficulties, but I never quite heard of refugees coming. I was told the refugees were not exactly from the United States. They were from other countries, came to the United States and then they came to Canada. In my ignorance of the particular circumstances I said: "Why come here? They are safe in the United States". They said: "They don't like it, you know, the Reagan administration and all these things are very difficult for them".
I see Mr. Clinton has indicated in some of his campaign speeches that there will be a change of direction in the United States. I say that without having specific knowledge of the American refugee determination system except to say I believe they have a system. They subscribe to the same laws as we do.
I have to disagree with those individuals who say to me that there is no third party, there is no safe country, we cannot accept people staying anywhere. I always say to them that if the United States is not a safe third country, I am not going to argue with them. They may not like the Reagan administration or its successor but how about other countries of the world? How about Britain? Britain has a system of law that as far as I know is very similar to Canada's. Can they stay in Britain? Is that a safe third country?' I am told the best idea is to have them all here in Canada. All the refugees should come to Canada.
There are many Canadians, myself included, that say no. I can see where an individual is at risk in his homeland, but I cannot go the next step and say it is not good enough if they have been to Britain to have their case decided, or any other country in the world. I cannot buy the argument that Canada is the only place, particularly when some of these critics were telling me six years ago that Canada was becoming a terrible place, that it was closing its doors. I disagreed with them then, I disagree with them today.
November 24, 1992

I see my time is just about up and I certainly want to share it with my colleague, Mr. Speaker. I ask members of Parliament to talk to their constituents, even talk to the individuals who are legitimately wanting to immigrate. It is a frustrating thing when people say to me: "Pm trying to bring in my relatives from the old country but the delay is horrendous" because much of our resources are directed toward security in the refugee determination system and it becomes very difficult for them to bring in their relatives from the old country.
It is in all our interests to support a bill like this which I believe strikes a reasonable compromise. There are many members of the New Democratic Party and many members of the Liberal Party who say this bill is not reasonable. I think it is. If we turn our mind back to just six years ago, that was a reasonable bill. I suggest this is a reasonable attempt to correct what each of our constituents is telling us is a problem.

Mr. Speaker, I listened carefully to the remarks of the member from Niagara Falls. I just want to say that when he talked about the issue of abuse, I do not think anyone in this House would disagree with him. We certainly are not promoting in any way an abuse of the system, for that matter an abuse of any system.
What we are trying to communicate to the government, as we debate this very complex bill, is the fact that we are being presented with cases on a regular basis where the system is abusing the individual. The judgment that the system is abusing the individual is being presented to us and as MPs, it is our job to make an evaluation whether or not the person is abusing the system or the system is abusing the individual.
I have had many cases where I have believed that the person was abusing the system and I told them that I could not help them. What we are concerned about is when we have a legitimate case and we need a mechanism to plug into that humanitarian and compassionate ground spirit which exists in the bill. We need a system that will react to that in an expeditious manner and respect the judgment that we are making on the individual cases.
Government Orders
Does the member not feel this is a reasonable request, when MPs are being presented with cases and are putting their own accountability on the line concerning whether it is a good case or a bad case? Let us assume that it is a positive one and we go to bat.
Does he not think it is reasonable that there should be some respect, that the system should react to our judgment in an expeditious way?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member touched on a couple of things.
He talked about the question of whether in some cases it is a question of the individual abusing the system or whether it is the system abusing the individual.
Let me say that I disagree with any system that takes years for there to be a determination. I agree with that in the refugee determination system, I agree with it in the criminal system and I agree with the idea that justice delayed is justice denied. It would be wonderful if we all lived until we were 300 and would have time for these things.
However, people's lives are short and a reasonable determination with safeguards is what we need. To that extent, I believe that a system that cannot cope within a reasonable period of time is a system that in a sense abuses the individual who was a part of that. I hope this bill will expedite that. I believe it will.
On the other hand, the member has said that he has seen examples. Certainly in my riding of Niagara Falls, from individuals close to it I have heard the opposite, of individuals abusing the system. What we want to do is strike a reasonable balance and that is why I support the bill.
With respect to the last part of the member's comments which he turned into a question: Should the opinions of members of Parliament be respected? Should they be listened to in the system? Of course they should be. We are in the business of trying to help individuals. None of us who has appointments each week in our ridings can escape the fact that people come in to see us and they want help.
They want us to expedite their case. They want us to cut through red tape. They want help from the system and therefore, to that extent, I agree with the hon. member that the system should take into consideration that members of Parliament have a legitimate concern in helping the people who live within their constituency and

Government Orders
that their views should be taken into consideration in the system.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I take your very subtle hint very subtly.
I find it interesting as we look at the conclusion of this debate that we have come to view the bill from the perspective of the member of Parliament. In most cases I think many of us would have an aversion to doing that. It speaks very much about the role that members of Parliament play in the immigration and the refugee determination system, partly because of the frustration so many people feel, partly because we are seen in many cases as the front line of government, partly because those that need our help with the system have a different type of political culture than we do.
I have been quite involved because of the influx of Bulgarians and eastern Europeans to St. John's and other parts of Newfoundland and I have quite willingly and actively made their case before the minister, before the IRB and certainly before the department in the agency process.
I can tell you with some pride that we have had small but very important results. The one I take the greatest satisfaction from is the Neuman Boykoff case where the minister in the national interest granted a minister's permit.
We have heard a number of comments about the minister's office and the department and their ability to respond. We have over the last few days heard a litany of cases. I too could stand here and rhyme off a series of
cases that I am not satisfied with but it is important to recognize that we have a perspective problem sometimes.
The department deals with over one million applications a year from all over the world to come to this country. This year we are expecting to admit 250,000 people. My view on those numbers is well known. I hope it can be increased. It benefits our country, particularly the regions and provinces like mine.
When we look at the concerns and the numbers of problems, it is important that we look at it in the perspective of the volume that is being dealt with, not only inside Canada but by those who represent this country on the front line around the world.
My friend from North Island-Powell River raises some concerns about our ability to be responsive in different parts of the world. It is important that we recognize that not only the flexibility but the initiative to be responsive is one the things that is important and is contained in Bill C-86.
Before I leave the minister's office-and God forbid that I defend the Minister of Employment and Immigration, particularly after what he has put me through in the last five months-but one great frustration the minister's office and the department has is the Privacy Act. A number of times I have found myself standing before the minister making a case when he quite simply was only able to say no to me. I was able to find out after the fact that the base of the case I was making was erroneous. I was factually wrong. The position of the minister and the department is that they are unable to make a case. I have been part of that. I suspect I will be part of it again. However, it is a situation they find themselves in and that we all find ourselves in.
We have heard about the most difficult problems we as members of Parliament face and as members of Parliament we reflect what our constituents see and that is the question of visitors' permits. One thing this legislation does is remove an assessment of the whole family whether they are coming to this country on a visitor's visa or not. We have discussed a series of amendments on how best that problem can be dealt with. One of the problems of setting criteria is that it becomes a condition against what we must give a visitor's visa for. Despite the
November 24, 1992

fact that criteria are met and we know the visitor may be inclined to stay in the country, we are not able to say no.
One of the better suggestions came from my colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River who talks about the bond. However, one downside is that the bond becomes something that is either not able to be collected upon or becomes a fee. I believe there is a nub there that should be pursued. People that want to come to this country are repeatedly denied access, quite often after coming here successively with no problem. It is something we must be able to respond to over a period of time.
One of the other great concerns that has been expressed is the question of family reunification. That continues to be a concern. We have heard a number of things said about it. There is no question that the ability to process applications more quickly is going to benefit those who have a focus on family reunification. The change in the assessment of applications from a post by post basis to a global basis not only will make the assessments faster for most people, but it will make them fairer. Whether you apply in Delhi or apply in London, your application will be assessed relative to all the other applications, not just those in the post that you have applied to. The busier posts will not demand applicants wait longer.
The flexibility that we talk about is also found in the minister's ability to set up centres of excellence. He has made it clear this will not apply in areas such as family reunification, but it will allow us to move our resources around to respond to the needs of demand, be it in the Punjab or wherever. Perhaps because there is a real focus for investor applicants in a certain area, we will be able to set up a focused processing centre, a centre that specializes in one particular area.
In terms of family reunification, I think it is important to recognize that Bill C-86 says that in the case of refugees, dependent children or family in that sense will be assessed with the refugee. Medical provisions that would normally apply will be waived and it is hoped that will allow for family reunification of refugees in as quick a period as six months.
There was a comment a little bit earlier that involved the question of race and ethnicity and preference in the system. I thought I did not need to remind this House
Government Orders
about the application of the charter to the government as it relates not only to people in this country, whether they be citizens or not, but people around the world.
I think it is very important that we recognize the source of immigration into this country. Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by making a few comments about why we need immigration to Canada.
I am sure all of my colleagues on both sides of the House as well as Canadians in general will agree that if we are not to allow immigration to Canada, by the year 2011 we will start to see a decline in terms of our present population.
To that extent that will pose a tremendous challenge to both the government as well as to the people of Canada in terms of the shrinking tax base in Canada. Simply put, by the year 2010 we will have almost double the amount of people on the retirement role in terms of people who are receiving pensions. We will have a shrinking in terms of the work force and, as such, we will have less taxes being paid to the government coffers.
That by itself is a good reason why we have to look for means and ways in order to do two things: first, continue to provide the quality of services to the people that they are accustomed to. At the same time, that will be good reason for us to say that without immigration, we will not be able to survive as a nation for very long.
The hon. member mentioned the fact that the vast majority of immigrants to Canada come from Third World countries. That is true and I want to tell him why. Simply put, it is because historically immigration to Canada has always been from countries where they have depressive regimes, a lack of economic opportunities, civil wars and so on.
All these people who have come to this country since the very early days up until now have come from countries where opportunities were not available. Certainly another factor why we are not getting immigrants from Europe is because Europe is faced with the very same situation we are faced with. That is a decline in terms of the population in Europe. The birth rate in Europe is in the same category as that in Canada. They do not have enough production in terms of population in order to sustain the population growth.
That is why we do not see many people coming from Europe to Canada. The other reason is that they have good opportunities in Europe and there is no reason for them to emigrate.
