moved that Bill C-305, an act respecting the award of the Victoria Cross, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to finally be able to rise in this House to speak to my private members' bill, Bill C-305, an act to restore the Victoria Cross. It seems to have taken a long time to get to this point.
I presented Bill C-305 for first reading in this House on October 2, 1991. In the interim, I have been very encouraged by the support that the principle incorporated in this bill has generated across the country. It is also most gratifying to see the support that the Victoria Cross has received within this House.
I have members on both sides of the floor offering support and encouragement for the reinstatement of the Victoria Cross as Canada's premier military decoration. The Victoria Cross is a simple piece of bronze suspended from a crimson ribbon. The bronze is cast in the shape of a cross with the royal crest and simple inscription for valour. The cross is made of bronze taken from a cannon captured during the Crimean War.
The decoration is older than the dominion of Canada. It was first instituted by Queen Victoria in 1856. One of the first Victoria Crosses issued was to a Canadian. Lieutenant Alexander Dunn from Toronto won his Victoria Cross in the Crimea in 1856 during the famous charge of the light brigade. Since then, 93 Canadians have received the Victoria Cross.
Lieutenant Colonel Fred Tilston of Toronto recently passed away, leaving two living Victoria Cross recipients in Canada, Charles Cecil Ingersoll Merritt and Ernest Smokey Smith, both of whom live in British Columbia. They earned their Victoria Crosses during the Second World War.
Across Canada we hear of many stories about the heroes who have won the VC. It is interesting to note that the third Canadian to win a Victoria Cross was
Private Members' Business
William Hall. William Hall was from Nova Scotia and he was black. His award for gallantry was presented in 1857 at a time when members of his race in the United States were still in slavery.
Canada Post recently did a beautiful vignette on Valour Road in Winnipeg. The nation notes with sadness the passing, and reports on the health, of any recipients of the Victoria Cross whenever they fall ill or pass away. The Victoria Cross has a significance that is too important to lose.
If we allow the Victoria Cross to disappear, our nation is diminished. For that reason, the debate this afternoon is extremely important. The Victoria Cross is a prominent symbol for Canadians. It is a symbol of our history, our heritage and respect not only for those who have earned the Victoria Cross through their gallantry but for those who fought along side of them. They fought in defence of liberty, freedom and peace.
It is also important because there is a proud tradition in this country, a military tradition, that most Canadians do not know or understand. Canada is a peace loving nation. We have never initiated a war and, God willing, we never will. It is not the Canadian nature to attempt to take by force of arms that which is not our own.
We have answered on several occasions the call to arms in defence of liberty and freedom. What is important in this debate and important in this House is that we understand that the courage and bravery recognized in the 93 Canadians who have received the Victoria Cross still exist.
We still have brave, courageous men and women who even today serve under the flag of the United Nations, proudly wearing the Canadian flag on their shoulders. They are willing to undergo personal risks and exhibit extreme bravery. Canadians make a contribution to peace and freedom far in excess of the expenditures of our country, but that is another story.
For those who serve today, the premier military decoration ever awarded to a Canadian is not at this time available. It is not recognized in the Canadian honours and awards system.
Canada has evolved on the road to independence. The evolution of a Canadian system of honours and awards began in 1967 and was implemented in 1972. At that time, through an omission, the military decorations

November 24, 1992
Private Members' Business
awarded to Canadians were all basically dropped, deleted or ignored.
It was suggested that separate Canadian military decorations would eventually be established and the Victoria Cross may be replaced by a distinctly Canadian decoration. Twenty years later no decision has yet been announced.
The Prime Minister rectified one oversight when he indicated that all Victoria Crosses won prior to 1972 could still be properly worn as the premier decoration. However, no provision has been made for any such medals to be awarded after that date. That is why we are here today engaging in this debate.
I became aware of just how seriously Canadians consider this problem when I was talking to a Royal Canadian Legion Branch in Sylvan Lake. At that time I explained why it no longer existed in the Canadian honours and awards system. It indicated to me in very strong language that it did not want just an explanation, it wanted the medal reinstated. It challenged me and asked me to do something about it. It is because of that branch and because of the hundreds of other veterans who have been encouraging me that I stubbornly persisted in pushing this bill forward.
This bill is written to establish a Canadian Victoria Cross. It proposes that it be distinctly Canadian, the premier decoration for bravery and would be incorporated into the orders of precedence of the Canadian honours as the senior gallantry award. Victoria Cross records would be maintained at the chancellery at Government House and costs associated with administration would be assumed by the Canadian government for Canadian purposes. Any future changes to the royal warrants would be issued by the Queen of Canada.
I feel very strongly that the principle of retaining the Victoria Cross not only has my support and the support of a majority of members of this House, but the support of all veterans' organizations, many serving members of the Armed Forces, the Monarchist League of Canada and the support of thinking Canadians.
The Royal Canadian Legion at its convention in 1986 passed a resolution petitioning the Prime Minister to restore the Victoria Cross as an award made to members
of the Armed Forces for valour. Again, this year at its convention in Quebec City it unanimously endorsed a similar resolution asking the Government of Canada to retain the Victoria Cross as the highest available decoration for valour. It added that the responsibility for recommending and awarding the Victoria Cross should rest with the Government of Canada with the investiture made by the Governor General as the representative of the Queen in Canada.
Bill C-305 has been endorsed by many members of this House. I thank the many members who have written in support and offered encouragement of the bill. I am also encouraged that the Prime Minister is on record in the Legion's magazine as recognizing the special place of the Victoria Cross in the history of the Armed Forces. The Leader of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition has also written in support of it, as has the leader of the New Democratic Party.
By presenting this bill I implore the government to heed the call of Canadians to respect our military tradition and our heritage, to establish military awards to recognize potential bravery and courage on behalf of our serving military personnel. I encourage it to follow the lead of Australia and, with the consent of the monarch, to re-establish the Victoria Cross of Canada as the premier military decoration. In so doing we are honouring the 93 brave Canadians who have been recognized. We also honour those who fought beside and in the tradition of them. We honour an award that was first presented by Queen Victoria to a Canadian.
Many times we debate in this House bread and butter issues, issues that have to do with the stomach and the wallet of the nation. We are talking here of an issue that affects the heart and soul of that nation. This is not an expensive issue. It costs this country very little to recognize bravery, courage, commitment and sacrifice. It costs very little. Ib those who have been recognized with Victoria Crosses, the cost to them in many cases has been horrendous.
Last week I paid tribute to the late Colonel Fred Tilston who, while showing extreme bravery at the battle of Hochwald Forest in 1945, was wounded three times and eventually lost both his legs. It cost the nation very little to give him the Victoria Cross and recognize his extreme bravery. What it cost Col. Tilston is far more than that.
November 24, 1992

We all pray that no Canadian ever need face armed conflict or go to war against another. It was just two years ago that Canadians joined other forces of the United Nations to free Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. Today Canadian peacekeepers are active in 12 countries and those brave men and women in many cases face danger on a daily basis. We do not have a military decoration to recognize any who show extreme bravery in those circumstances. It is reprehensible that we are in that situation and it is reprehensible that we have not done anything to rectify it.
An argument has been made that this is perhaps not a proper topic for a bill before the House of Commons. A valid argument was made that honours and awards are properly established by the royal prerogative rather than a bill of the House of Commons. I have been convinced that this might be so and I would not want this bill to detract in any way from the significance of the Victoria Cross, but I do feel it is important that all members in this House have the opportunity to express themselves.
I would offer that nothing can detract from the significance of the Victoria Cross and it should be re-established.
By carrying on with this debate I want to indicate very strongly the arguments and reasons for reinstating the Victoria Cross. I do not intend to let my efforts to get this medal reinstated as the premier Canadian military decoration stop at all. I intend to pursue the matter with the Prime Minister, the Minister of National Defence, the Minister of Veterans Affairs and whoever else need be contacted.
The Victoria Cross is an international honour. It is available still to members of the Commonwealth. Like other international honours such as the Nobel Prize, the Victoria Cross has transcended geographic and political boundaries. Ninety-three Canadians have been awarded the Victoria Cross for conspicuous acts of bravery and daring. This links us to a tradition going back to the Crimean war. It is older than our nation. The Victoria Cross will always have a special place in our honours and awards system and that place should be front and centre.
I will try and be short because I know there are several other members who want to address the issue as well.
Private Members' Business
The Victoria Cross is very special to Canadians and nothing that we can say or do in this House is necessary to embellish the bravery of those Canadians who have been recognized with it. Likewise, we cannot diminish the significance of those that have been awarded. It is going to stand throughout our history as the premier military decoration ever awarded to a Canadian. Even if through some mishap we fail to restore it to the forefront of the Canadian honours and awards, we cannot dimmish its significance. Our failure to do so will diminish our significance because no nation that aspires to greatness, and Canada is a nation that has the potential for greatness, will ever achieve it if it refuses to honour those who made that greatness possible.
It would be our shame if we were to sit back and let this important part of our history and heritage be lost. Canada should have its own military honours. The fact we do not is a ludicrous oversight and it makes no sense for us when establishing military honours to discard the tradition of an award that has been revered by all Canadians; a tradition that reminds us that when we are called to battle Canadians have always conducted themselves with honour and with bravery.
I have been very inspired by reading the reasons for the awarding of several of the Canadian VCs. Canadians do not know enough of our military history and heritage. Perhaps that is one of the reasons that we have allowed the travesty that this bill attempts to correct to occur.
In my riding alone there are three items that are connected to the Victoria Cross. Canadian Forces detachment in Penhold has recognized with Mynarski Park the bravery of Pilot Officer Andrew Mynarski who lost his life during the Second World War while attempting to save a comrade who was trapped in a burning Lancaster bomber. The medal that his family received was small consolation for the supreme sacrifice that he bravely paid to attempt to save a comrade.
I have also been watched very closely by members of the R. L. Zengel V.C. branch of the Royal Canadian Legion in Rocky Mountain House. Sergeant Ray Zengel was a native son of Rocky Mountain House. He won his Victoria Cross in the First World War and his medal is a prized possession of that branch.

November 24, 1992
Private Members' Business
Why do Canadian youth not know the stories of our heroes? Why do we not celebrate their accomplishments and thank God for their contributions and sacrifices? If we as a nation truly appreciate what they did, we would all understand the significance of this piece of bronze and we would all join in demanding its reinstatement.
Stories of valour extend into every province and area of Canada. I attended a 100th anniversaiy in my riding last summer and one of the most significant elements in that family's history and anniversary was the Victoria Cross, won by one of the members, Corporal Alex Brereton.
Two weeks ago during remembrance services in all comers of this nation we listened to the intonation: "At the going down of the sun and in the morning, we will remember them".
We all replied then, along with millions of grateful Canadians: "We will remember them". Yet every year fewer Canadians can remember the sacrifices of those who served in wartime and even fewer who can remember the faces of those who paid the supreme sacrifice.
To lose the Victoria Cross is to lose the faith of those who selflessly sacrificed and contributed so much to our development as a nation and earned us the freedom and strength of the nation we enjoy.
I am asking in this bill that we not allow the symbol of recognition given to the bravest of the brave to be diminished. I am asking that we restore the Victoria Cross and all it symbolizes to its rightful place of predominance in Canadian honours and awards.
The time allotted today does not possibly allow for all members who would like to speak on this topic to do so. It is an important issue, one that many members should be participating in. Therefore I would ask the unanimous consent of the House to make that possible by designating Bill C-305 as a votable item.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to take part in this debate. I congratulate the member for Red Deer on his initiative in bringing forth this private member's Bill C-305 to reinstate the Victoria Cross.
I have long advocated that Canadians should take more pride in themselves, our institutions, our history and our heroes. The Victoria Cross, even though it was originally an award from the British government, has long epitomized Canadian heroism. People from around the world admire and respect those 90-plus Canadians who have been decorated with the highest military award that could be possibly be won by a Canadian serviceman or woman.
The Victoria Cross is the stuff of which legends are made. As has been mentioned by my hon. colleague from Red Deer, the names on the honour rolls, including Billy Bishop, Smokey Smith and one person from my home province, Frederick Thornton Peters, the only resident of my province to win the Victoria Cross, summon up the vision of selfless heroism in the face of danger. To read the stories of these people who were awarded the Victoria Cross, one cannot imagine what they went through in the face of so much danger. It was not uppermost in their minds at the time; certainly they had no thoughts of receiving the medal. A year ago I had the opportunity to travel to Italy on a pilgrimage with veterans. One of the men I spoke about, Smokey Smith, was there and we visited the area where he received his medal.
It is my sincere wish also that the young people of Canada could see these heroic figures in the same light as they see many of the heroes of other countries, especially the United States. I believe that we in this country are far too quick to look beyond our shores and ignore many times the people and much of the heritage of our own country. The reinstatement of the Victoria Cross as a Canadian award would help to alleviate this problem.
I strongly support the reinstatement of the Victoria Cross as the highest Canadian award for valour and would urge members of this House to support this private member's bill. We are certainly mature enough as a nation to retain this honour with its historic name
November 24, 1992

and have it remain as the greatest symbol of Canadian heroism.
I agree that the medal could be awarded along the lines it is in Australia, with Canadians making the determination as to whom should receive the medal. It will therefore take its rightful place as the greatest honour a Canadian could possibly receive. I hope each of us in the Chamber will take the stand on this matter that our conscience dictates.
Since I have been in the House I have been troubled by the relative lack of importance which sometimes is attached to private members' bills and to the whole process of bringing private members' bills before the House.
I feel the executive branch of government does not always attach much importance to the backbenchers on either side of the House. A very talented group of members have been elected to the House of Commons, but under the constraints imposed by rigid party line and party discipline many of their good ideas never come to the floor of the House of Commons.
I had sincerely hoped that during the constitutional discussions and all the parliamentary hearings the message would have come through loud and clear that members of this House should be given a greater role in the formulation of legislation.
To my mind one of the major reforms which must be carried out in this country is the strengthening of the role of members of Parliament. From talking to other members in this House, I know there is widespread support for this particular piece of legislation, the one we are discussing today. It is one of the many good ideas that can come from the ordinary member.
Whether or not this legislation ever passes will depend unfortunately on whether or not the executive branch of government wants it to. Individual members of Parliament should have more input into the drafting of legislation and should in my view be able to initiate more legislation from the floor of this House.
It was mentioned this afternoon on another piece of legislation that maybe we should not have that say. I believe that members of Parliament, members of this House, have to play a more vital role in the running of
Private Members' Business
this country because Parliament is the very essence of democracy.
The people who are here have been sent to the House with a specific job to do. I believe they could be doing a better job if they felt more freedom in the matter of introducing and supporting legislation, wherein committees could play a bigger role in amending legislation and legislation coming back here. It could all be part of the process.
The people of Canada have grown cynical about the political process and about politicians as a whole. Perhaps part of the reason is that they see us many times blindly following party discipline when we should be speaking and voting as our conscience dictates. That would be good. We should be speaking and we should be voting that way.
This is a good piece of legislation. It will help us redefine and re-emphasis the things that make us proud to be Canadians. I am very proud to support this bill and I urge other members to do likewise.

Mr. Speaker, I take pleasure on behalf of my colleagues in the New Democratic Party in supporting the private member's bill put forward by the hon. member for Red Deer and supported by the hon. member for Hillsborough. I want to congratulate the hon. member for bringing the bill forward. If there is anybody in this place who is opposed to it, I would sure like to know who it is.
The Victoria Cross is recognized as the top medal for valour in Commonwealth countries and is even shown that kind of regard in other countries. Private Members' Business
In 1972 the Victoria Cross was left out of the Canadian system of honours and awards. In 1990 another sequence of medals was introduced, for example the Cross of Valour in the highest position. The Victoria Cross is no longer in the sequence but is validly worn if it was won before 1972.
It is very possible that one of these times a Canadian will do something of the order that earns the Victoria Cross, carrying out his duties under the United Nations flag. If that should happen and that person's exploits were of the kind, quality and calibre that has happened before with other recipients of the Victoria Cross, then it should be issued as the first order in Canada. It should lead the list of the orders of precedence. I do not know why they had to meddle around with this, if you will pardon the expression.
I was somewhat noted for being a Canadian nationalist. I swore an oath when I became a member of this House to bear allegiance to the Queen. She is the Queen of Canada and there is no reason on earth why, if there is another award of the Victoria Cross because it can be won in peacetime as well as wartime, she cannot present the award or the Governor General as the Queen's direct representative here.
The Royal Canadian Legion has made it very clear, very plain. Last April Comrade Fred Williams wrote to the Prime Minister and stated that the Royal Canadian Legion most strongly requested that any new bravery award system included provision for the permanent retention of the Victoria Cross as Canada's highest military award for valour.
We can do no less. I urge my colleagues from all parties to put this legislation through without any wrangling about it, and I do not think there will be. This is one area where all parties are unanimous in support of this bill. The only other thing I would like to see happen is some improvement being made to the small pension, the small honorarium awarded with the VC. It is a carryover from before the First World War. I sure would like to see something done with that, not so much in an effort to repay them, because we can never fully repay the recipients, but to put something a little more material behind the award in addition to the award itself. I would like to see the minister and his department come up with
improvements in the awarding of a pension in conjunction with the Victoria Cross.
I had the great pleasure, as my hon. friend from Hillsborough mentioned, of being in Holland, Sicily, and Italy on the 40th anniversaiy of the liberation of Europe, and many parts of it liberated by Canadians. We had in our group with the minister Fred Tilson and Smokey Smith who never did anything or said anything to draw attention to themselves. However, when others found out there were two VC winners with us, it was interesting to see how many people went to see them just to have the honour of meeting them and getting their autographs.
You have to hear Smokey Smith's version some time of how he won that medal. His version was that a German soldier filled his brand new battle-dress tunic with holes after he had just had it tailored with box pleats and dry-cleaned. This soldier shot him and put holes in his jacket. He said he got mad and took his Sten gun and stitched him from bottom to top. You ought to hear him tell it. He is very funny and a very good person.
It was also a pleasure to meet with Col. Merritt, who mingled with all of us. I was only an OR during the war and always looked up in awe at majors and colonels and so forth, but he was one of us. We were proud to have both him and Smokey Smith with us. I will never forget that trip if I live to be 1,000.
I want to leave this in the hands of the House in the hope that there will be no question about supporting the bill. Like the hon. member for Red Deer, I appreciate the indulgence of the House to make this a votable motion which means it gets another couple of hours debate. I hope then other hon. members will take the opportunity to get up, even if it is only for five minutes, to say things about this and put their support behind it.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am proud to have the opportunity to speak in favour of the private member's bill before us today. It addresses an issue that has been of concern to many members of this House for some time now.
For 20 years Canadians have not been eligible to receive what has traditionally been the highest award for valour bestowed in time of war, the Victoria Cross. As a
November 24, 1992

seconder of this bill, I am anxious to see it passed into law so that the situation may be rectified.
Many of us have worked with individual veterans, legion branches and constituents on the issue. I believe there is a strong desire among the public to see members working to pass a bill such as this one. Public confidence in Parliament is strengthened when members are seen to be responding to the clear wishes of thousands of individual Canadians.
Established in 1856 by Queen Victoria, the Victoria Cross was, for over a century, the highest award for gallantry available to Canadians in time of war. Since that time only 93 Canadians have ever won the VC: four before the Boer War; four in South Africa; 69 in World War I and 16 in World War II.
As a unifying symbol for this country and others throughout the Commonwealth, the VC is unsurpassed. Canadian recipients have come from all walks of life, from every province and from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds but the common denominator for all of them was their shared loyalty and sacrifice for this country.
When my hon. friend's bill was introduced here in October of last year there were three surviving recipients of the VC in Canada. Since that time one has died, leaving two living reminders of our past and of our duty to ensure that their heroism is not forgotten.
I need not remind hon. members of the place the Victoria Cross holds in the hearts of tens of thousands of Canadian veterans. Over the past few years many veterans have felt that their contribution to the country has been forgotten or demeaned.
The reintroduction of the Victoria Cross into the Canadian honour system will go a long way to confirm our respect for Canadian veterans and for the men and women who serve today in our Armed Forces.
Private Members' Business
Tell that to the Canadians who won the VC in World Wars I and II. Tell that to the families of those who died in the defence of our country. I do not believe for a moment that they saw themselves as anything except Canadians answering the call of their country.
Although Canada was bom out of compromise, her maturity as a nation came in battle. Vimy Ridge, Dieppe, Normandy all were battles in which we fought alongside our allies: Britain, France and the United States. We did not enter these conflicts as a vassal state. We entered out of commitment and loyalty to our friends in World War II, out of recognition that war was necessary to rid the world of a monstrous evil.
I am not trying to glorify the horror of war. The suffering and sacrifice that came from our involvement wounds us to this day. It is true that the Victoria Cross was introduced by Britain in the aftermath of the Crimean War. Indeed, VCs were forged from the canon barrel employed in that conflict.
The VC is truly an award that cuts through national borders. Soldiers from many Commonwealth countries ranging from Australia to Pakistan and New Zealand have won the cross. So is its British origin an argument against reinstatement? Certainly not.
We have retained countless traditions that date back to past years. In Quebec, the civil law code finds its origins in the Napoleonic code. Our country's most distinguished lawyers are honoured with the designation Queen's Counsel. The Governor General represents the Queen in Canada. Tradition and the continuity of symbols is part of what binds a country together.
By reinstating the Victoria Cross, we are acknowledging not only the value of our history, but also are expressing confidence in our maturity as a nation. This bill provides for a Canadianized Victoria Cross. We would not be alone in this.

The proposed system would see the Governor General bestow the Victoria Cross on the advice of the Canadian government of the day. All responsibility for the cross would rest in Canada, the administration, ceremony and so forth. In this way, there would be no doubt as to the true nature of this decoration, an honour conceived in an era long past, but preserved and strengthened with an eye to the future.
By voting for this bill, we are sending a very clear message to the Canadian public. We are listening to their concerns. They have told us that we have an obligation to conserve that which is most noble in our past, to respect the wishes of those veterans who sacrificed so much, to maintain an honours system that both reveres our Commonwealth traditions and at the same time is uniquely Canadian.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to rise in this debate. I want to thank the hon. member for Red Deer in bringing forward this bill to Canadianize the Victoria Cross.
This is a very important matter. It has been discussed and debated for 20 years in Canada. I find it incredible that we allowed the Victoria Cross to be dropped from the awards and honours Canada gives out. I find it incredible that we allowed the Trudeau government in 1972 to drop it from the awards.
I have stood up on several occasions in the House to encourage the government to reinstate the Victoria Cross. I also co-sponsored the bill of the hon. member. He deserves a lot of credit, as do other members of the House, for pushing this issue to the point where now we have a votable bill before the House of Commons. I hope that members of the House of Commons will see to it when this does come to a vote that it is passed.
On June 9,19921 rose on a statement pursuant to S.O. 31.1 would like to read into the record what I said at that time:
Mr. Speaker, I strongly believe that our government should
Canadianize and restore the Victoria Cross medal as the highest
accolade for an act of valour in the face of the enemy.
In 1972 when the previous government brought in the new Canadian orders of bravery the Victoria Cross was omitted. I believe it is time this policy be reversed. The Victoria Cross should be reinstated and awarded by the Governor General on the advice of the government of the day.
After listening to the many views of many veterans on this issue, I strongly believe the Victoria Cross should once again resume its position as a distinguished part of Canada's awards for gallantry.
I still hold that position very strongly today. A few days later, I got up and asked the Associate Minister of National Defence if she would Canadianize the Victoria Cross. I want to read into the record my question and the answer. I was very disappointed with the answer and I urge the government not to interfere with this private member's matter and to allow members to vote on it as they wish. I would hope and I think that most members will vote in favour of this bill to Canadianize the Victoria Cross.
The question I asked on June 12, 1992 was:
Does the minister support the restoration and Canadianization of the Victoria Cross as Canada's highest medal for valour in the face of the enemy?
The minister responded:
I know my hon. colleague's interest in this subject, but I would like to point out to him that the Victoria Cross is a British medal bestowed by the Queen. It is not a Canadian medal. Obviously Canadians would still be eligible to receive it. It is given for extraordinary valour in the face of the enemy. We hope we do not have to face such an enemy.
But, at the same time, within Canada we have been developing our own system of honours and awards over a number of years. The final component of that would be to develop our own awards for valour in the face of the enemy. That work is not complete but it is ongoing.
I am sure that the hon. member would agree that it is important that we have within Canada a method of recognizing bravery of Canadian men and women in the Armed Forces.
I want to say we can have that method and that method is to bring forward a Canadian Victoria Cross. That is what we should do. We can Canadianize it. We can recommend through the right channels to the Queen that this Victoria Cross be awarded to particular people rather than put aside this tremendous symbol of courage, tradition and history that is so esteemed by so many veterans across this country.
Earlier this year in the Legion magazine of March 1992, the Victoria Cross was discussed. It pointed out that Australia has become the only Commonwealth country to nationalize the Victoria Cross. The Legion magazine
November 24, 1992

states: "The Queen signs letters patent authorizing the Governor General to award the VC on the advice of the Australian government. The Queen has made it clear that even the Commonwealth republics can advise on the Victoria Cross". That is what the Monarchist League of Canada chairman, John Aimers, said. "The Victoria Cross could be made more Canadian. Certainly we would want it given out only on the advice of the Canadian government. I think all the royal societies are united on this one." The article goes on to talk about how the Legion for years has been calling for the previous government and this government to Canadia-nize the Victoria Cross and to pay a little bit of attention to this very important matter.
Canada is a young country but we have traditions and symbols. This is a part of our history and perhaps it is time to Canadianize the Victoria Cross, to retain it as a part of our history. It is so important. Too often in our society we devalue the symbols and traditions of the past, but this is one that is important to not only veterans but I am sure it is also important to those members of the Canadian Armed Forces who are serving today. I am sure they would like this award to be there for their valour if it is needed in times of conflict.
In closing, I just want to say that I support this whole-heartedly as I believe many members do. I want to pay tribute once again to the member for Red Deer who, with courage, presented this even though there were indications that the government and others in society wanted to do away with the Victoria Cross. He persisted and his efforts have been laudable and admirable. I hope that we can see in the next short while the announcement that the Victoria Cross will be Canadia-nized.

Mr. Speaker, further to a question I asked on May 5 this year, the Secretary of State informed me that they were in the process of completing agreements with British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Ontario and that it was expected the conclusion of these agreements between the provinces and the federal government would be announced very shortly.
This was six months ago and there has been no announcement so far either by the government or by the provinces and I wonder what is happening.
It is rumoured that an agreement in principle was concluded by the federal government and the provinces. This agreement, worth $177 million according to some people, is about to be approved by the federal cabinet, and the minister is expected to make an announcement a few days from now.
Meanwhile, we are still waiting, and I wonder what this government thinks about the promises it makes, the

Adjournment Debate
expectations it raises and how it has disappointed certain groups, especially official language minority groups which are greatly dependent on the federal government for their survival.
Young Franco-Ontarians are still waiting for the minister's official announcement on the Cite Collegiale, a post-secondary institution, the College du Nord, the College du Sud and the College du Sud-Ouest. Franco-Albertans are still waiting for the announcement concerning their community centre in Edmonton. Franco-Manitobans are still waiting for an announcement about infrastructures and institutions that will help guarantee their survival.
For the past 10 years, our Constitution has granted Canadian parents the right to educate their children in minority language institutions. Although these are legal rights, governments lack the political will because they have no way of making these institutions, these minority-managed school boards a reality without the assistance and support of the federal government.
On August 31 I wrote to the premiers of all the provinces, including Ontario, British Columbia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Alberta to ask about the status of this constitutional right of francophone minorities to manage their own educational institutions, as they do in New Brunswick and Quebec.
Ontario, Manitoba and British Columbia have yet to answer my letter. The premier of Alberta informed me of a bill, now in second reading, which deals with the issue of school boards for the language minority in Alberta. Saskatchewan mentioned a bill tabled before its legislature adjourned. The Newfoundland Minister of Justice told me that a report would be submitted by the end of the school year on structures for the administration of schools by the francophone language minority in Newfoundland.
Despite these few rays of hope, here in Ontario a number of municipalities have passed resolutions against establishing French schools in Ontario. They include Georgian Bay, Campbellford, Fludson, Petawawa, Elliott Lake, Brampton and other municipalities which have endorsed a recommendation to oppose the creation of francophone school boards in Ontario for financial reasons. These municipalities refuse to recognize the constitutional rights of Ontario's francophone minorities. This is a deplorable example of intolerance and lack of understanding on the part of the majority.
It is not always easy to live in a minority position. It is not always easy to survive in provinces where there are groups that are fiercely opposed to the very existence of a Canada that sees itself as the very expression of linguistic duality.
Time is of the essence. Today, November 24, 1992, I want to ask the parliamentary secretary: when can we expect a clear and specific announcement of the Conservative government's position on establishing minority school boards and thus providing the possibility of establishing certain institutions that are essential if we want to survive as a minority and as Canadians in our province?

Mr. Speaker, there is a crisis in Montreal. Between one-quarter and one-third of the people in the city are living on some form of social assistance. When I walk along the streets, almost one in every five people I meet is unemployed.
In some areas of my riding, like Snowdon and Cote des Neiges, every fourth person is out of work. Tkken together, the unemployed people in Montreal could fill the Olympic Stadium more than five times. Retailers, manufacturers, builders, industrialists, as well as our people, have been touched by the massive unemployment in the city. There is not a family who does not have a sister, friend, brother, mother or father who has not lost a job as a result of the made-in-Canada recession, brought on in large part by this Conservative government's poor fiscal and economic policies.
In particular, the anglophone and allophone communities have been extremely hard hit by the recession. They have not been encouraged by the report from the Conseil de la langue frangaise showing that even fully bilingual members of their communities suffer discrimination in the work force, including the public sector despite section 15 of the Official Languages Act.
Adjournment Debate
The recession has spared no one in Montreal. It has hit both men and women. It has hit people from all walks of life, be they professionals, managers, sales people or construction workers. It is hitting young people and old people.
I am deeply concerned about the welfare of the people of Montreal. I have often asked ministers in this House what they intend to do about this crisis in Canada's second largest city and the motor of the Quebec economy.
On May 15 the Minister of Employment and Immigration answered by flaunting a job training program that he supports out of the unemployment insurance fund. Today people who have started this program are unable to finish it because this government refuses to continue to contribute to this fund.
Since July, people who applied to this program have been turned away. This Tory policy for upgrading our work force is just a sham and these people who themselves contributed money to this fund while they were working on the understanding that there would be some money for them when they needed it. These people are honestly trying to improve their own job prospects and this government is letting them down.
In fact, a recent Conference Board of Canada report has concluded that this Conservative government's economic policies are responsible for this recession. This government's policies are, in large measure, responsible for the number of people out of work in Montreal. The government's policies of high interest rates, high taxes and deep spending cuts have made the recession in Canada longer and deeper than anywhere else in the world. Its policies have actually added to the deficit and contributed to unemployment by killing economic growth in this country. Now, with 204,000 people out of work in Montreal and 1.5 million in Canada, we learn that the finance minister plans to cut government spending yet again on unemployment insurance, Old Age Security and family support. This will not stimulate the economic growth and will not help the people who are in Montreal to find work.

November 24, 1992
Adjournment Debate
When will this government produce and fund concrete measures to help people get back to work? That is a very serious problem and it is time this government undertook something.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of Employment and Immigration, I wish to respond in greater detail to the question of May 15 by the member for Mount Royal.
The government shares the concerns of all Canadians with the effects the economic slowdown has had on job creation, unemployment and ultimately the increase in those receiving social assistance.
To reduce Canada's growing social assistance caseload, the government is undertaking several different initiatives. First, the government has negotiated agreements with all provinces to enhance the employability of social assistance recipients. These agreements marshall a combined federal and provincial effort of $400 million to give social assistance recipients priority access to employment programs.
Second, a $50 million pilot project has been established with the provinces of British Columbia and New Brunswick to help social assistance recipients obtain employment and achieve self-sufficiency. This project is breaking new ground in government's approach to helping those on social assistance and will hopefully pave the way toward a more effective income support system in the future.
Third, the government's current strategy in the area of training will ensure better opportunities for all Canadians, including those at risk of ending up on social assistance. Under the labour force development strategy, actual spending for labour market programming is expected to increase by 62 per cent over a four year period, from $2.5 billion in 1989-90 to $3.55 billion in 1992-93.
This year federal labour market assistance will help about 900,000 unemployed Canadians. This assistance, combined with a growing economy, will contribute toward reducing welfare rolls and lead to economic selfsufficiency for many Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to follow up on questions I asked in this
House earlier this year and, indeed, as recently as this afternoon, of the Secretary of State for External Affairs with respect to the plight of Christine Lamont and David Spencer, two young Canadians who are currently serving 28-year prison terms in Brazil.
Christine Lamont and David Spencer went to Central and South America because of their deep commitment to social and economic justice for the poor, the powerless and the dispossessed in that region. In 1989 they were caught up in an appalling nightmare which started on December 17, 1989, with their arrest.
The subsequent trial of Christine and David was in many ways a miscarriage of justice, conducted under conditions of extreme politicization. Indeed, the judge himself indicated that he was under tremendous pressure from police and politicians to convict all 10 of the accused.
Cardinal Ams, the Archbishop of Sao Paulo who has been intimately involved from the beginning of this whole affair, has spoken out on his profound conviction of the innocence of Christine and David; indeed has written a letter to the Canadian Prime Minister in this regard.
Christine and David were convicted and then to compound the injustice, to change from miscarriage to in fact travesty of justice, the Court of Appeal increased the sentences to 28 years. As foreigners under Brazilian law, they are not entitled to parole. This indeed is far worse than a life sentence in Canada.
Under Brazilian law, indeed the Brazilian constitution, there is provision upon the request of a foreign government for the Brazilian government to expel foreign nationals in its prison. This is a power which has been exercised in a number of occasions. The minister today in the House suggested that somehow this was unprecedented. That is absolutely false. There are many precedents for this. Indeed, just recently a Chilean national was expelled pursuant to the request of his government.
In June of this year, the justice committee unanimously urged the government-unanimously, all parties-and the Secretary of State to call for the expulsion of Christine and David under Brazilian law. They said that waiting for appeals, waiting for a transfer of offenders treaty, was unacceptable and placed them at risk. That risk is even greater now, particularly after the tragic riot
November 24, 1992

and deaths and murders of 111 prisoners in a Brazilian jail in late September.
The justice committee last week reiterated its unanimous appeal to the minister to seek the expulsion under Brazilian law of Christine and David. The Prime Minister said that he has spoken with the President of Brazil, now impeached, seeking justice for these two people. We do not know if he sought expulsion, but certainly we hope so.
I want to take this opportunity to once again call upon the government and the Secretary of State for External Affairs and the Prime Minister to wait no longer, to stop their shameful stalling, to listen to the justice committee, to listen to the voices of Canadians, to listen to the families and to seek the expulsion of Christine Lamont and David Spencer under Brazilian law.
Their lives may be at risk. Certainly a grave miscarriage of justice has been done, and the time is long overdue for this minister to act on behalf of these two Canadian citizens.

Mr. Speaker, as the Prime Minister confirmed in his response to the hon. member's question on June 17, he did indeed raise the matter of Christine Lamont and David Spencer with the President of Brazil during the earth summit in Rio de Janiero. He raised it again in letters to President Collor when he was still in office, and more recently to President Franco. The position of the government in this case has been guided by respect for the due process of law. At the moment there are two appeals pending in this case before the federal courts in Brasilia, one on whether the trial court had jurisdiction to hear the case and the other on the length of the sentences.
At the direction of the Secretary of State for External Affairs, our ambassador in Brasilia has been actively pressing to ensure that the judicial process continues without delay. He has learned that a decision on whether the appeal on the sentences will be heard, and indeed perhaps a decision on the appeal itself, will be forthcoming in the very near future.
He has also learned that the Brazilian Attorney General has submitted an opinion to the court that the
Adjournment Debate
sentences of the individuals involved should be differentiated according to their degree of involvement in the kidnapping. This could result in a reduction of the sentences that Christine Lamont and David Spencer received.
We understand that the opinion of the Attorney General is given considerable weight in these cases. Should there be undue delay in this appeal, however, or should it be denied, the situation would be reviewed again.
I would also point out that a transfer of offenders treaty with Brazil was signed on July 15 which when in force would enable the return of Miss Lamont and Mr. Spencer to serve any remaining portion of their sentences in Canada with the benefit of Canadian provisions.
Our ambassador has been actively lobbying Brazilian ministers, the leaders of the two chambers of the Brazilian Congress and the chairmen of the legislative committees responsible for reviewing the treaty to move it as quickly as possible through the Brazilian approval process. All have assured him that there are no problems that might delay ratification.
Finally, I would like to assure the House that everything possible is being done to ensure the safety and welfare of Miss Lamont and Mr. Spencer while in prison. The Consul General in Sao Paulo has visited them frequently and made numerous representations to the Brazilian authorities to improve the conditions of their imprisonment.

Mr. Speaker, this week a cargo plane bringing $2 billion worth of cocaine was seized in Quebec, thanks to the superb effort of the RCMP, the Canadian Air Force and other agencies.
Let me congratulate them and the thousands of officers who each day try to keep these terrible drugs out of Canada. Yet for each shipment that is caught, untold other shipments of illegal drugs slip through our border, move into our streets and ruin the lives of thousands of Canadians.

November 24, 1992
Adjournment Debate
Countless reports and statistics tell the story of this tragedy. A recent survey conducted by the Children's Aid Society of metro Toronto found that 12 per cent of parents use crack. An estimated 156,000 Canadians use cocaine and 36,000 use LSD.
The fact is stronger drugs like the comeback of heroin in the streets of Toronto are on the increase. The recent study by a major health insurance company found that the increase in cocaine use in Quebec ranks number two in all of North America, second only to Washington, a city fraught with street crime, drug wars and abuse.
We know that alcohol and drug abuse are responsible for between 70 to 90 per cent of all crimes committed in Canada. The Addiction Research Foundation recently estimated that drug abuse costs the Canadian economy $11.5 billion each year. Our youth in particular are becoming victims of drug use.
In the face of the alarming increase in hard substance use like heroin and crack we need measures that tackle the program twofold: to help cut off the supply through tougher policing and air surveillance with seizure of drug profits and second, and most important, to look at choking the demand.
The fact is we cannot succeed in addressing Canada's drug abuse program by getting at the suppliers. It does not work in the United States or in Europe and it is not working in Canada. What we need and what we are waiting for from this government is a coherent policy that looks at demand, that builds drug education programs for youth, that builds rehabilitation programs to get users off drugs and help them rebuild their lives; in other words, prevention and cure.
I urge this government to improve programs and to look also at the serious rise in the measure of prescription drugs. The reports from constituencies across the country, especially in Montreal and Toronto, are to the effect that the money, the programs and the educational initiatives must work together. We know that $270 million has been put into the substance abuse program, but we still do not know, six months later, how this money is being spent. Is it spent with community groups and volunteer associations in building drug prevention
and rehabilitation programs that deal with the cause as well as the symptoms of substance abuse?
I am anxious to hear from the parliamentary secretary tonight, not some round-up of general statistics, but specific examples on what this government is doing with and for the people affected.

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member for Davenport for raising this most important issue, one which concerns all Canadians, especially those with children. It gives me the opportunity to tell how the government is dealing with harm caused by substance abuse.
In 1987 we announced Canada's drug strategy. Phase one brought $210 million over five years. Seventy per cent of this money was directed at prevention, education, rehabilitation and treatment. Communities right across the country have been mobilized.
The results were that first-time alcohol use by youth between grades seven to 13 has dropped from 84 per cent to 65 per cent. Between 1987 and 1991, 1,100 native communities participated in addiction awareness week, compared with only 84 communities in 1987.
At the end of March the hon. Minister of National Health and Welfare confirmed this government's longterm commitment to reduce harm caused by substance abuse. Two hundred and seventy million dollars, an increase of about 18 per cent over phase one, was allocated to Canada's drug strategy. The strategy still emphasizes community participation. Once again, over 60 per cent of the strategy money is geared toward prevention in which the hon. member is interested.
This government continues to be determined to tackle alcohol and drug abuse. Canada's drug strategy continues to provide both financial and technical assistance to local communities.
Thirty million dollars over five years will be given to community action programs and $77.5 million will be allocated to cost shared treatment programs in partnership with the different provinces. These moneys will target groups that our nation-wide consultation recommended.

Mr. Speaker, I gave notice of my intention to transfer this question to debate on the adjournment motion because it sat on the Order Paper for eight months without the courtesy of a response.
The question concerns the International Year for World Indigenous Peoples, an idea originally advanced by the Grand Council of the Crees of Quebec through its ambassador at the UN, Ted Moses.
1992 has marked the 500th anniversary of Columbus landing in America, the beginning of the colonial era which saw the annihilation of aboriginal people by disease, wars, starvation and slavery. More recently governments have followed a more subtle process of cultural genocide using annihilation of self-esteem, destroying of people's roots or their contact with the land.
Around the world this has resulted in social problems such as chemical abuse, suicide, dependency on welfare, problems that colonial powers could easily argue are self-inflicted or based on character flaws of the oppressed.
There were many people, myself and my party included, who hoped that 1993 could mark the era or the end of an era of idolizing colonizers and the beginning of a period during which the injustices of the colonial period would be recognized and redressed.
There are some 300 million indigenous people in the world, but how many will be represented at the United Nations during the inauguration of the international year? How many will Canada be assisting to travel to New York to participate in the deliberations? How many is Canada consulting on the draft of the resolution which Canada has lobbied to present, proclaiming the official beginning of the international year on December 10? Indeed, how many have been involved in planning with the Government of Canada its activities at home and abroad during the international year?
When I attempted to find out the answer I was embarrassed. No wonder the minister's office called my office yesterday and asked me not to raise the question in the House.
Adjournment Debate
In 1990 Canada assembled a disinformation crew from External Affairs and Indian Affairs to travel around Europe sanitizing the Oka crisis. More recently this bunch intercepted a report of the transnational corporation subcommittee of the UN working group on indigenous peoples on the James Bay Cree and circulated it to government departments for comments prior to its publication. The Cree of course were not one of those consulted.
Unfortunately the same wrecking crew has been put in charge of Canada's participation in the International Year of Indigenous People which is turning into a whitewash of Canada's record on aboriginal people while trying to maintain an international image of sanctity. The result is that Canada is contributing perhaps $90,000 to $100,000 to the UN voluntary fund and its over-all budget for the international year is so small that it will have no impact whatsoever on indigenous people around the world.
Canada says it has no money to assist Canadian aboriginal organizations to send their representatives to New York. Canada even tells them that their speeches would have to be vetted by the government if they joined the Canadian delegation so that they would not embarrass the government. Canada is only taking one aboriginal person, Chief Wendy Grant of British Columbia, to be a part of its federal team at the inaugural meeting.
Canada is paying to have representatives of the departments of External Affairs and Indian Affairs to argue full time against the collective rights of world indigenous people and against the principle of self-determination, even though these principles are enshrined in the United Nations charter. They are working on a resolution proclaiming international year which Canada is going to present, and according to one international participant Canada's resolution is getting weaker and weaker, draft four is worse than draft three, draft five is worse than draft four. Canadian aboriginal organizations have not been consulted in the resolution until the last possible minute.
The worst result is that Canada has used the international year as an opportunity to divide and conquer aboriginal people at home.
